a-wyoming-frog-in-pierre.raw_content:
SYTYCFanon

A Wyoming Frog in Pierre
For more stories click here

Friday, 3:07 PM
Watkins Corner Store

Rain poured hard on the windshield of the broad, white vehicle. The van belonging to the SCP Foundation parked right outside the convenience store. Its driver, Beau, sighed as he took the keys out of the ignition. Of all the days to get stuck in the field.

I’ve got plans tonight. So being that you’re free, I’m… delegating this to you. Dee's words echoed in his head. They were the bottom of the SCP Foundation’s totem pole, but then, Beau was the dirt underneath it. If he didn’t want to accept orders from them, his only available option was walking out the door and hanging up his cleaning supplies for good.

“You don’t think I have plans for tonight too?” He pocketed his keys. “… I mean, I don’t, but you could have at least considered it.” Beau lamented to himself before getting out of the car. His first step down out of the van splashed his beige uniform with muck and dirt from the wet ground, and he grimaced.

Grabbing a few basic supplies, he rounded the van and saw a man standing just outside the store. He was, simply described, a messy looking person. Beau less politely thought of him as white trash, seeing his tangled, grungy hair poking out from his flip flop sandals. The white wife beater tank top and sullied blue pants looked just as old and musty as they smelled. His hair clung to the back of his balding scalp for dear life, while his tired expression made him look done with life. He seemed unbothered by the hefty rain. Beau hoped this wasn’t the man who owned the store-

“Hey, you, janitor man - you my hookup to get this fuckin’ thing outta my store? I didn’t buy this damn thing to have freaks shittin’ on my floor all night!”

Goddammit. The janitor shook his head, trying to at least pretend to be willing to do the job of his own volition. “Hello, sir. I’m Beau. Beau Larkin of the Safe Cleanup Professionals. We sanitize, cleanse, and polish. I hope to be of service.”

He seemed somewhat appeased by the professionalism. The man shook his hand, glancing down at Beau’s mud-spattered uniform with a furrowed brow. “Yeah, uh - Tony Watkins, nice to meetcha.”

“So what can I do for you, Mr. Watkins? I was told you had a mess in your store that was scaring away your paying customers?”

The man, Tony, became quite incensed. “Mess? Yeah I got a friggin’ mess - There’s this smelly, green fuck sittin’ on my fridge, eating my whoppers, and wrecking my shit. And listen, my weird as fuck customers don't even care that he's there. The real problem is he’s stinkin’ up my freakin’ store! And when I try to get him to leave he pulls a Glock on me - and, uh, the police think I’m high! So you get in there, janitor man, and you either ice the fucker or get him outta my friggin’ store! This is almost as bad as those freaks with the big meat ball!”

“Well, animal control is one of our specialties.” Beau lied through his teeth. “Why don’t I have a look? Just let me grab my supplies from the truck.” He tried to maintain the professional demeanor, both to appease Tony, and also to try to keep his own sanity.

Beau went to retrieve his full duffel of the remaining cleaning supplies, cursing himself once again for not buying a taser, and followed the man inside. He was greeted with a half destroyed store, shelves and products spilled out everywhere. Any tubs of icecream, or snack bags, were open and drained of their contents. The cabinet behind the register that contained the cigarettes had been ransacked, and there was a pungent aroma of weed in the air.

“Oh God, it looks like a tornado went through here. What exactly did you say did this?” Beau looked back at the owner, fighting to hold his nose while in such close proximity to the other man.

The fat store owner chuckled, and Beau was uncomfortably attentive to the way he… undulated. “Heh, yeah I don’t have a damn clue. Why don’t you, uhhh, take a look yourself?”

When they turned into the aisle, Beau didn’t see anything besides the general devastation until he turned his head and nearly jumped back in surprise. Sitting there was a large brown tree frog the approximate size of a grown ass man. He was smoking a lit menthol cigarette while his hands were splayed out, the four fingers fiddling with random debris strewn about. He was sat atop a Hershey’s brand freezer.

Now, Beau was not a total stranger to strange animals… but this was fucking ridiculous.

“Hey, you, frog thing.” The creature slightly lifted its head, blearily looking at the fat man. “Yeah I’m talkin’ to you, you little shit-stain. I got the janitor on your ass now. Your days are numbered -”

There was a loud clicking noise, as the frog cocked the Glock and pointed it at Tony. Beau and Tony exclaimed loud noises of surprise, and ducked out of the way as a bullet whizzed by and blew up a vat of Nutella, spilling its contents onto the floor - and Beau’s already dirty shirt.

Breathing deeply and averting his hyperventilation, Beau asked Tony why he hadn’t called hazardous animal control of some kind if the frog had a gun.

Tony, in response, looked at Beau like he’d grown a second head. “I got rats, and you can’t sell no food in a place with rats. Your uh, Sucking, Cleaning, Proselytizing or whatever doesn't report to the state. And I ain’t payin’ no damn animal control fees.”

Beau didn’t know how to respond, and wrangled the topic back to the matter at hand. “Listen, okay? Cleaning I can do. Removing this guy? I mean, he’s got a gun, I don’t really-”

“I ain’t paying you to mull it over. This frog better be gone by the morning or I’m uh… I’m calling your manager.”

“Whoa, whoa. No need for that.” Beau swallowed at the thought of anyone except Dee chewing him out. “I’ll… figure it out.”

“Attaboy! Just make sure you lock up afterwards.” He tossed a spare key to Beau and started to head out.

“What? Wait, are you not gonna stay to make sure that I finish the job?”

“Nah, I’ve got plans with the, uh, ladies, ya know? I mean come on, it’s Friday, I got a couple of bills burnin’ a hole in my pocket. I got better things to do than fuck around with a frog after the 9-5. So uh, get to it, janitor man.” The store owner walked out, and Beau looked away from his filthy attire. He felt a lot better being mercifully separated from the malodorous store owner. He peered around the corner at the frog, who seemed to be fiddling with the Glock before tossing it to the floor. Beau then looked down at the key in his palm as he heard the door shut behind Watkins.

“Yeah, it’s Friday. And everyone has plans.” He turned his head over to the frog, who was ominously much closer than before, having approached silently. It was looking at the janitor expectantly.

“Yo.” The frog greeted, taking the cigarette out of its mouth and flicking some ash onto the tile floor. It had a deep gravelly voice, not what Beau had expected.

“Uhhhh, yo?” Beau responded, forcing himself to have nerves of steel he didn’t really possess.

“I’m Gary. You said your name was Beau?” The frog took another drag from the cigarette as he finished speaking.

Beau blinked twice, figuring he must have heard him outside. “Yeah, it is.” The frog took several more drags from the stick, and Beau watched it as a sweat bead dribbled down his wet face. “So what brings you to, uh, the corner store? Didn’t know frogs liked… convenience?”

The frog dropped into a splayed out sitting position, his body making a profoundly loud ‘splop’ noise as it collided with the smoothly tiled floor. “I love frozen dinners and menthols, brother. Can’t get enough of ‘em. This place has ‘em in spades.” ‘Gary’ seemed to believe that was reason enough, and went back to taking drags from his cig.

“Strange combination.” Beau hoped that this would be a lot smoother than he was fearing it would have been. “Soooooo, is there like a home I can help you get back to?”

The frog shook his head in the negative, which really meant he shook his entire torso more or less. “Ain’t goin’ home. Too much heat on me.”

“Heat? What… what did you do?” Beau leaned in, morbidly curious.

“I’m famous. You never heard of the Chugwater Frogman?”

“What the hell is a Chugwater?”

“Town in Wyoming. I’m their local frogman. Got tired of their bullshit.”

Beau hoped there would be more of an explanation, or at least justification, but he was left wanting. “Well you can’t stay in this corner store, the uhm… the owner is gonna kill you. With a gun. A really big gun.” Beau lied once again.

Another wisp of menthol wafted through the air. “Nah, I could take it.”

“A… a bullet? You’re saying you can take a bullet?”

“Yeah. I've had worse.”

“L-like what?”

“Got hit by a car once.” The frog looked Beau dead in the eyes, and said, “Do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?”

Beau blinked and swallowed. “No, I don't think… I don’t think it works like that.”

“Have you ever been shot?”

“…Have you?”

The frog stood up, his feet making little plap noises on the floor as he paced. “Listen, this place has everything a frogman could need, except for a nice Olive Garden platter, flat screen, and a DVR so I can watch Big Brother… sittin’ on a sofa, rubbing my belly, scratchin’ my-”

The janitor loudly cleared his throat. “Well, look, that sounds awesome but my job right now is to clean this place up. If you want, I can get you somewhere wet at least? Do frogs like wet things?”

“I mean, I’m more of a branch guy, but wet is a good start.” Beau thought that over…

Five minutes later, Beau had situated Gary on a mop handle he had haphazardly placed inside of a trucker shower stall. Gary was gripping onto it, using it like a branch. It was liable to fall apart any second, but the lukewarm water cascading down Gary’s back giving him a serene expression oddly made it all worth it. Sort of.

It was much less fun when he had to start wheeling his mop bucket setup back and forth from the main store back to the janitor closet, the same room with the shower stall, and began the arduous task of the clean up. It was going to be quite a long one, between all the spilled food and drinks, cigarette ashes, poop–

“Hey wait a minute.” Beau said, looking at Gary as he was dumping out the bucket into the mop sink. Gary opened his eyes, and looked annoyed that he was being talked to. “Why did you shit all over the store - aren’t you like, basically a human frog?”

“Frogman.”

“Right, so… Why? Do they not house train frogmen in Wyoming?”

“I am burrow trained, thank you very much. That Tony guy just reminds me of the damn truckers who’d come through. Always littering, fouling up the water. One of the reasons I left. I don’t take shit from nobody, but I will shit on people who I think deserve it.”

Man, Beau wished he could do that. Well, not shit on people’s floors - that would be weird. But he definitely liked the rest of that attitude. “Yeah, that Tony guy is… not great. I’d go so far as to say I think he’s an ass.”

“Dude he smells like shit, at least you only smell like bleach and sadness.”

The man winced, looking down at his sullied beige uniform. “Oh, you can tell?” He felt the soreness in his legs more profoundly, and decided to take a break by sitting down and leaning against the wall. “I guess I am kinda sad.”

The frogman looked over, peering out of the stall. “What’s gotcha down? You seemed pretty confident back there, like a… real cleaning professional.”

Beau sighed heavily and leaned on the handle of his mop. “A cleaning professional that barely makes above minimum wage. But it’s not the money that’s the issue, I just… can’t shake how lonely I feel in this town, y’know? I’m committed to cleaning up Pierre’s messes but I’ve got no one to be in a mess with.” He looked up at the creature.

The frogman gazed at him with his large, unreadable golden eyes. There was something… utterly human in those eyes. “No one? Don’t most people have someone else at home?”

Beau shrugged. “Well, I have a roommate, but we don’t really talk to each other, just kinda exist in the same space. He wouldn’t give me the time of day even if I was made of money. We just pay rent together.”

A few moments passed, as the shower continued to run its water, splattering over the floor. Then, Beau looked up from the blue and grey tiles as a brown froggy foot stepped into view. “I didn’t really have anybody either. It’s always just been me, not even really sure where I came from but this place seems better than Chugwater. It’s got better janitors at least. And it has more than one restaurant.”

Beau smirked. “What’s your favorite place to eat?”

“Wendy’s.”

Beau sat up straighter. “No way dude, me too! You fuck with a vanilla frosty?”

Gary sat down with a wet noise next to Beau. “That and the breakfast baconator with the swiss cheese sauce.”

The janitor nodded. “I feel you, I feel you. Guy I live with only ever wants to order out Little Caesars - no taste whatsoever.”

“Fuck Little Caesars, they’re cheap for sure but they taste like cardboard - and I’ve eaten cardboard so I should know.”

“Absolutely! I don’t wanna eat a fuckin hot and ready every weekend because he can’t pick up some actual groceries.” A few moments passed, the soothing sound of water on tiles the only noise in the store.

Then, Gary turned to Beau. “Yo, I got a twenty, let’s slam some Dominoes when you’re done.”

“Wha… Really?” Beau asked, stunned.

“Yeah bro, least I can do after making you pick up my crap -”

A raucous shattering of glass followed by a series of thuds resonated through the store. The two budding fast food aficionados turned to see two people fall through the window on the side of the room. One man crashed directly onto the floor with a big thunk, while the woman landed more gracefully than her partner, though still not very professionally.

“Cracker down….” The man on the ground groaned.

“For the record, the Pizza Hut in this town is better than the Dominoes.” The woman remarked, cleaning herself off before grabbing her partner and hoisting him up to his feet. Beau noted she used a mechanical arm that seemed to make lifting a grown man effortless. “Chudley, you're making us look bad.”

“Why you gotta say fuck me then? They didn’t see that.” He gestured to Gary and Beau, before desperately looking at them. “You guys didn’t see that, right?”

“Wha…. can I help you?” Beau was too dumbfounded to even react to Chudley’s question.

“You can help us by staying out of the way, you damn spook.” Maria scoffed.

Beau blinked, and Gary chuckled. “Spook?”

“We’ve been keeping an eye on things around here and we know you SCPeople are government contractors. Things that go bump in the night disappear around y'all, and you're always driving around in those fuckass Chevy vans."

“I’m just a janitor, lady, and I don’t have to explain myself to someone who clearly doesn’t know how to use a damn door!”

“It’s because they’re from Wyoming.” Gary replied dryly.

“How can you tell?”

“None of us know how to use doors. I broke that window over there when I came in.” Gary pointed at another, larger window that was busted in.

“I’m just gonna state for the record that I suggested we use a door but my partner wanted to make an entrance in style.” Chudley stepped forward. “This is Maria Johnston, aspiring parabiologist. And I am Greg Chudley, aspiring has-been.”

Gary looked at them with contempt. “Parabiology isn’t real, dipshit.”

“It will be a real science, once I have a chance to study you.” Maria explained. “Then those chuds at UW will finally see my brilliance.”

The realization hit Beau like a bag of bricks to who he was dealing with, “You two are college students?”

Maria glared as though Beau had just said the dumbest thing she’d heard in her entire life. “Yeah man. We’re on summer break. Do you not spend your summer break chasing your local cryptid 500 miles to the capital of South Dakota?”

“What the fuck is wrong with you two?” Beau asked, only to be easily thrown aside by Maria’s metal limb.

Maria pointed an accusing thumb at Greg, who was pretending not to sift through the bags on the ground of the convenience store. “Blame this one’s trust fund for enabling our insane tendencies. Now, Gary. We’ve come a long way for this. I promise I’m not going to hurt you but I need to take you back to my lab.”

The frogman made a loud, furious squeaking noise. “No! I’m not going anywhere! Why does everyone want something from me?!” Gary leapt with an incredible force across the room to distance himself from the pair. A lightbulb went off in his big froggy brain as he saw a discarded firearm on the ground. “Wait, fuck this.” Gary picked up his Glock 17 and took aim at the collegiate duo. Chudley immediately threw his hands up but Maria held her ground. “You two skeddaddle! I want to go to Dominoes with Beau and maybe roll around in the soil, just for a bit, and then binge Big Brother.”

If the right side of Beau’s body was aching from being thrown to the floor he would have felt all warm and tingly on the inside. He couldn’t remember the last time someone had wanted to hang out with him.

“I don’t understand why you're being so loyal to Dominoes. Pizza Hut has the superior pepperoni.” Maria continued to overcompliment Pizza Hut ignoring the fact she was being held at gunpoint.

“If you like wet dog food! Those ‘ronis are too damn soggy. Stop trying to change the subject! I will shoot.”

“I can take it.” Maria smirked confidently.

“Stop being cocky, have you ever been shot before?”

“I’ve had worse.”

“Can’t be worse than getting hit by a car, do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?”

“Depends on what kind of car. A smart car’s worth of bullets is a lot of bullets but not as many bullets as a Sedan. ”

“Well I could get my boy to go get the van, could you take a van’s worth of bullets?”

“I survived getting hit by a train. There isn’t a single amount of goddamn bullets that I wouldn’t be able to take!” Maria screamed, and Gary clicked the safety to the off position.

Beau crawled over to Chudley, who had just found a fifty in the corner and pocketed it. He whispered, “What…is happening right now?”

“Oh, uh, if you haven’t noticed Maria is very…. Particular about the semantics of things. She’s never one to lose an argument, no matter how ridiculous. Or if a frog is pointing a gun at her.”

“Riiight. Should we intervene before she gets herself shot?”

“I dunno man, she’s got me convinced. Maybe she could take a cruise ship’s worth of bullets.”

Beau tuned back into the conversation and decided he needed to act. He immediately jumped in between the pair again when Gary chambered a round, and they’d gotten somewhere near space shuttles worth of munition endurance.

“Look, none of you can take any FUCKING amount of bullets. Listen, Gary is the only person in this god forsaken town who seems to want to give me the time of day and I’m not gonna let you take him.” Beau said, impassioned. “This town is full of oddities, weirdos, and whatever the hell else. I would know. Just fucking pick one to write your paper on but not him, please.”

Maria stared daggers through Beau at the annoying frogman behind him but the janitor noticed a slight change in her demeanor before she turned around.

“Fine. You can take him.” She said over her shoulder.

Beau slumped with relief, and a little confusion. “Huh? You’re not gonna clock me again?”

A belabored sigh came from her as she walked away. “We've got other leads to follow up on. I'm sure we'll find something for the thesis.” She turned around and signaled for Chudley to follow. “We'll be seeing you around Skipper, dunno how lenient I'll be next time.”

Chudley gave a wordless salute as the pair disappeared into the night, leaving Beau and Gary dumbfounded.

“Hey, uh… You really mean all that?” Gary asked as he put away his Glock into the place in which he was storing it.

Beau looked down at the slightly shorter creature. “Of course man. You think that old coot has got more loose bills lying around? I saw that Chudley guy pocket a fifty.”

“I like the way you think, funny man. Let's get ourselves some Dominoes money!”

And so Beau and Gary finished cleaning up the store to the best of their ability all except one mess that Gary had left behind in Tony's office, as well they managed to loot at least sixty more dollars from the backroom.

Their weekend would be filled with delicious pizza and getting Gary set up back at Beau's place. While they didn't have an extra television just for Gary , they did have a window with a convenient angle to their next door neighbor whose favorite show just happened to be Big Brother.

I've had worse.” “L-like what?” “Got hit by a car once.” The frog looked Beau dead in the eyes, and said, “Do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?” Beau blinked and swallowed. “No, I don't think… I don’t think it works like that.” “Have you ever been shot?” “...Have you?” The frog stood up, his feet making little plap noises on the floor as he paced. “Listen, this place has everything a frogman could need, except for a nice Olive Garden platter, flat screen, and a DVR so I can watch Big Brother… sittin’ on a sofa, rubbing my belly, scratchin’ my-” The janitor loudly cleared his throat. “Well, look, that sounds awesome but my job right now is to clean this place up. If you want, I can get you somewhere wet at least? Do frogs like wet things?” “I mean, I’m more of a branch guy, but wet is a good start.” Beau thought that over… Five minutes later, Beau had situated Gary on a mop handle he had haphazardly placed inside of a trucker shower stall. Gary was gripping onto it, using it like a branch. It was liable to fall apart any second, but the lukewarm water cascading down Gary’s back giving him a serene expression oddly made it all worth it. Sort of. It was much less fun when he had to start wheeling his mop bucket setup back and forth from the main store back to the janitor closet, the same room with the shower stall, and began the arduous task of the clean up. It was going to be quite a long one, between all the spilled food and drinks, cigarette ashes, poop– “Hey wait a minute.” Beau said, looking at Gary as he was dumping out the bucket into the mop sink. Gary opened his eyes, and looked annoyed that he was being talked to. “Why did you shit all over the store - aren’t you like, basically a human frog?” “Frogman.” “Right, so… Why? Do they not house train frogmen in Wyoming?” “I am burrow trained, thank you very much. That Tony guy just reminds me of the damn truckers who’d come through. Always littering, fouling up the water. One of the reasons I left. I don’t take shit from nobody, but I will shit on people who I think deserve it.” Man, Beau wished he could do that. Well, not shit on people’s floors - that would be weird. But he definitely liked the rest of that attitude. “Yeah, that Tony guy is… not great. I’d go so far as to say I think he’s an ass.” “Dude he smells like shit, at least you only smell like bleach and sadness.” The man winced, looking down at his sullied beige uniform. “Oh, you can tell?” He felt the soreness in his legs more profoundly, and decided to take a break by sitting down and leaning against the wall. “I guess I am kinda sad.” The frogman looked over, peering out of the stall. “What’s gotcha down? You seemed pretty confident back there, like a… real cleaning professional.” Beau sighed heavily and leaned on the handle of his mop. “A cleaning professional that barely makes above minimum wage. But it’s not the money that’s the issue, I just… can’t shake how lonely I feel in this town, y’know? I’m committed to cleaning up Pierre’s messes but I’ve got no one to be in a mess with.” He looked up at the creature. The frogman gazed at him with his large, unreadable golden eyes. There was something… utterly human in those eyes. “No one? Don’t most people have someone else at home?” Beau shrugged. “Well, I have a roommate, but we don’t really talk to each other, just kinda exist in the same space. He wouldn’t give me the time of day even if I was made of money. We just pay rent together.” A few moments passed, as the shower continued to run its water, splattering over the floor. Then, Beau looked up from the blue and grey tiles as a brown froggy foot stepped into view. “I didn’t really have anybody either. It’s always just been me, not even really sure where I came from but this place seems better than Chugwater. It’s got better janitors at least. And it has more than one restaurant.” Beau smirked. “What’s your favorite place to eat?” “Wendy’s.” Beau sat up straighter. “No way dude, me too! You fuck with a vanilla frosty?” Gary sat down with a wet noise next to Beau. “That and the breakfast baconator with the swiss cheese sauce.” The janitor nodded. “I feel you, I feel you. Guy I live with only ever wants to order out Little Caesars - no taste whatsoever.” “Fuck Little Caesars, they’re cheap for sure but they taste like cardboard - and I’ve eaten cardboard so I should know.” “Absolutely! I don’t wanna eat a fuckin hot and ready every weekend because he can’t pick up some actual groceries.” A few moments passed, the soothing sound of water on tiles the only noise in the store. Then, Gary turned to Beau. “Yo, I got a twenty, let’s slam some Dominoes when you’re done.” “Wha… Really?” Beau asked, stunned. “Yeah bro, least I can do after making you pick up my crap -” A raucous shattering of glass followed by a series of thuds resonated through the store. The two budding fast food aficionados turned to see two people fall through the window on the side of the room. One man crashed directly onto the floor with a big thunk, while the woman landed more gracefully than her partner, though still not very professionally. “Cracker down….” The man on the ground groaned. “For the record, the Pizza Hut in this town is better than the Dominoes.” The woman remarked, cleaning herself off before grabbing her partner and hoisting him up to his feet. Beau noted she used a mechanical arm that seemed to make lifting a grown man effortless. “Chudley, you're making us look bad.” “Why you gotta say fuck me then? They didn’t see that.” He gestured to Gary and Beau, before desperately looking at them. “You guys didn’t see that, right?” “Wha…. can I help you?” Beau was too dumbfounded to even react to Chudley’s question. “You can help us by staying out of the way, you damn spook.” Maria scoffed. Beau blinked, and Gary chuckled. “Spook?” “We’ve been keeping an eye on things around here and we know you SCPeople are government contractors. Things that go bump in the night disappear around y'all, and you're always driving around in those fuckass Chevy vans." “I’m just a janitor, lady, and I don’t have to explain myself to someone who clearly doesn’t know how to use a damn door!” “It’s because they’re from Wyoming.” Gary replied dryly. “How can you tell?” “None of us know how to use doors. I broke that window over there when I came in.” Gary pointed at another, larger window that was busted in. “I’m just gonna state for the record that I suggested we use a door but my partner wanted to make an entrance in style.” Chudley stepped forward. “This is Maria Johnston, aspiring parabiologist. And I am Greg Chudley, aspiring has-been.” Gary looked at them with contempt. “Parabiology isn’t real, dipshit.” “It will be a real science, once I have a chance to study you.” Maria explained. “Then those chuds at UW will finally see my brilliance.” The realization hit Beau like a bag of bricks to who he was dealing with, “You two are college students?” Maria glared as though Beau had just said the dumbest thing she’d heard in her entire life. “Yeah man. We’re on summer break. Do you not spend your summer break chasing your local cryptid 500 miles to the capital of South Dakota?” “What the fuck is wrong with you two?” Beau asked, only to be easily thrown aside by Maria’s metal limb. Maria pointed an accusing thumb at Greg, who was pretending not to sift through the bags on the ground of the convenience store. “Blame this one’s trust fund for enabling our insane tendencies. Now, Gary. We’ve come a long way for this. I promise I’m not going to hurt you but I need to take you back to my lab.” The frogman made a loud, furious squeaking noise. “No! I’m not going anywhere! Why does everyone want something from me?!” Gary leapt with an incredible force across the room to distance himself from the pair. A lightbulb went off in his big froggy brain as he saw a discarded firearm on the ground. “Wait, fuck this.” Gary picked up his Glock 17 and took aim at the collegiate duo. Chudley immediately threw his hands up but Maria held her ground. “You two skeddaddle! I want to go to Dominoes with Beau and maybe roll around in the soil, just for a bit, and then binge Big Brother.” If the right side of Beau’s body was aching from being thrown to the floor he would have felt all warm and tingly on the inside. He couldn’t remember the last time someone had wanted to hang out with him. “I don’t understand why you're being so loyal to Dominoes. Pizza Hut has the superior pepperoni.” Maria continued to overcompliment Pizza Hut ignoring the fact she was being held at gunpoint. “If you like wet dog food! Those ‘ronis are too damn soggy. Stop trying to change the subject! I will shoot.” “I can take it.” Maria smirked confidently. “Stop being cocky, have you ever been shot before?” “I’ve had worse.” “Can’t be worse than getting hit by a car, do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?” “Depends on what kind of car. A smart car’s worth of bullets is a lot of bullets but not as many bullets as a Sedan. ” “Well I could get my boy to go get the van, could you take a van’s worth of bullets?” “I survived getting hit by a train. There isn’t a single amount of goddamn bullets that I wouldn’t be able to take!” Maria screamed, and Gary clicked the safety to the off position. Beau crawled over to Chudley, who had just found a fifty in the corner and pocketed it. He whispered, “What…is happening right now?” “Oh, uh, if you haven’t noticed Maria is very…. Particular about the semantics of things. She’s never one to lose an argument, no matter how ridiculous. Or if a frog is pointing a gun at her.” “Riiight. Should we intervene before she gets herself shot?” “I dunno man, she’s got me convinced. Maybe she could take a cruise ship’s worth of bullets.” Beau tuned back into the conversation and decided he needed to act. He immediately jumped in between the pair again when Gary chambered a round, and they’d gotten somewhere near space shuttles worth of munition endurance. “Look, none of you can take any FUCKING amount of bullets. Listen, Gary is the only person in this god forsaken town who seems to want to give me the time of day and I’m not gonna let you take him.” Beau said, impassioned. “This town is full of oddities, weirdos, and whatever the hell else. I would know. Just fucking pick one to write your paper on but not him, please.” Maria stared daggers through Beau at the annoying frogman behind him but the janitor noticed a slight change in her demeanor before she turned around. “Fine. You can take him.” She said over her shoulder. Beau slumped with relief, and a little confusion. “Huh? You’re not gonna clock me again?” A belabored sigh came from her as she walked away. “We've got other leads to follow up on. I'm sure we'll find something for the thesis.” She turned around and signaled for Chudley to follow. “We'll be seeing you around Skipper, dunno how lenient I'll be next time.” Chudley gave a wordless salute as the pair disappeared into the night, leaving Beau and Gary dumbfounded.   “Hey, uh… You really mean all that?” Gary asked as he put away his Glock into the place in which he was storing it. Beau looked down at the slightly shorter creature. “Of course man. You think that old coot has got more loose bills lying around? I saw that Chudley guy pocket a fifty.” “I like the way you think, funny man. Let's get ourselves some Dominoes money!” And so Beau and Gary finished cleaning up the store to the best of their ability all except one mess that Gary had left behind in Tony's office, as well they managed to loot at least sixty more dollars from the backroom.    Their weekend would be filled with delicious pizza and getting Gary set up back at Beau's place. While they didn't have an extra television just for Gary , they did have a window with a convenient angle to their next door neighbor whose favorite show just happened to be Big Brother.

clipboard-avoiding-me.creator: xexnoncores
clipboard-avoiding-me.raw_content:
xexnoncores

This article contains CWs for: emotional abuse, and graphic depictions of emotional trauma.

Clipboard Avoiding Me by xexnoncores

⚠️ content warning ↑

Take the clipboard, write down on it.

Take the clipboard, write down on it.1

Take the clipboard

And your shaking fingers

And write down on it it.

It it it it

SCP-(REDACTED)

Just breathe. You are loved

Allegedly

Concepts come naturally to you. You’re a good artist, if you died then people would

Go on. Fill it in. Do your job.

Fill it in. Blood flows freely. Text doesn’t. It’s so easy to commit a hit and run.

Hey? Can I have X? I need it badly.

I need you badly.

I need you to tell me why you won’t talk to me anymore.

Why it came out of nowhere.

You’re just a few degrees too close to the skeletons in my closet.

Please don’t tell anyone how I lived once.

Cheap imitation

Artificial inflation

Intelligence is infinitely cheaper than a simple interest

My fear is the same thing as your own experience

Won’t change be the first thing that comes out?

ADDENDUM ██████-01: THE TERROR IN YOUR TEETH IS LIKE YOUR ENAMEL BEING STRIPPED

FEAR OF FAILURE APOPTOSIZING YOUR GUMS

Fear of reaching out

Let’s open the closet, shall we?

Don’t look at me

Who I used to be

10 out of 10 psychiatrists2 agree it was ███████

██ chess ██ chess ██ chess

Please play games with me again, chase me around like old times.

I only wanted your impossible

Improbably improbable impossible impossibility3

████████████

Speak it out. Write on the clipboard.

What do you see?

…

(Photos go here)

(Photos of me)

(Her)

(You)

(You looking at me)

Stop. There’s nothing there.

Stop! I said stop!

That’s more like it.

There we go.

Bleed, bleed, bleed, blood.

Draw blood through extended faults, fights, fires. How lousy of you to get burned, cutting yourself on the flames.

Failure. You will be hunted and made a prison’s martyr, because there is no one to justify your past actions.

Snap, run it through a plethora of administrative processes. Through a blackboxed database of all kinds of secret sectors you are not allowed to understand.

Look at me! Look at me! No, wait, stop! Only look at me if you like me!

Trauma? You mean that time when you ███████ ████ ███████ ████████████ ██████ ████ and ████████ ███ ███████ █████ █ ████████ █████████ ████ ████ ███████ ██████████ █████ ███ ██.

Yeah, she reported it as █████████. That’s not what it is, but people believed her. Maybe they’ll believe her again. The threat looms in your mind, always, every unanswered text, call, every time you don’t get what you want.4 Sorry, we’re not letting you classify yourself as a victim, because you were poisoned too. No, you don’t get to say you “grew out of it”, you need to stay damned forever. We need you to stay damned forever, we want you to die. It’s only natural. It’s the best for everyone. You ruin everything you touch, you don’t understand what you make, everything you create is wrong on an ontological level. You’ll always be a liar of some kind, because you cannot live a good existence. It’s just the truth. Sorry.

Sorry. It’s not our fault. You must understand, we’re doing this for your own ████████. Your best defense is killing yourself for this disgusting thing you call “kindness”.








fuck

im sorry.
































I only ask you don’t hate me, please?

Don’t speak ill of me if I have to leave.

I promise ██████ isn’t what happened.

I just…I just…

I don’t know what to say anymore.

I’m just afraid. Afraid of who I used to be.

I wasn’t a perfect v███. I’m sorry. I should have been, I should have taken them better.

I should have kept my mouth shut.

I should have killed myself like everyone who doesn’t talk to me anymore wants.































































Tap the clipboard. Record the anomaly again, D-19721.

1. The last text from them is on your phone.
2. Psychopaths in her words, she said the lawyer you contacted was an asshole.
3. That’s a double negative you idiot.
4. deserve

dig-u-better-dead.raw_content:
An "orphan source" is a radiation source no longer under regulatory control, usually because it has been lost, stolen or abandoned.

Thanatotherapy was developed in the 1960s by Prometheus Medical, one of the many subsidiaries of Prometheus Labs. A novel treatment for certain cancers, thanatotherapeutic techniques involve the targeted application of thanatic energy (also marketed as "omega radiation") to cancerous tissues. Unlike ionizing radiation, thanatic energy can be modified by a skilled thanaturge or necromancer to only damage cancer cells, leaving healthy tissues unharmed; Prometheus Medical cured dozens of previously-terminal patients in clinical trials, and in '72 they were getting ready for a full commercial roll-out.

Then the first patient died. And then they came back.

Thanatotherapy was shelved shortly after that. Spontaneous reanimation is bad optics, and mundane radiation oncology was catching up pretty quickly. The labs were mothballed, and the equipment put into storage. And there it would have sat, safely locked away, if not for the paratech crash and the subsequent breakup of Prometheus Labs.

An "orphan source" is a radiation source no longer under regulatory control, usually because it has been lost, stolen or abandoned. The most serious orphan source incident in mundane history was the Goiânia accident, which occurred when a cesium-137 radiation source was stolen from an abandoned radiotherapy clinic in Brazil; four people died, and two hundred and fifty were exposed to significant levels of radiation.

The Chanhassen Catastrophe claimed more lives in the first thirty seconds.

Ionizing radiation sources are all, broadly speaking, the same. You need a radioactive isotope; you need a container to hold it; you need shielding around that container. Every source of thanatic energy is different. They are born from tragedies, hundreds or thousands of deaths at the same place or time; the only attempts to systematize their creation have been prosecuted as crimes against humanity.

They are not as rare as one would hope.

Nearly every battle of the Second World War created a thanatic source, the death-energy concentrating around a particular totem: an officer's ancestral katana, a tank crew's lucky charm, or a particularly bloodthirsty general's corn-cob pipe. The same goes for the First: a blasted tree in no-man's-land, or the perforated skull of the first casualty. Before those were the Opium Wars, the Napoleonic Wars, the Wars of the Reformation; and after, Korea, Vietnam, the Congo. Humans are good at killing each other.

The most powerful thanatic source known to modern thaumatologists (excluding Mythic Age creations like the Atlantean Dead Mind) is the Volga Core, a roughly skull-shaped piece of furnace slag recovered from the ruins of the Red October steel plant after the Battle of Stalingrad. Exposure to the Volga Core can turn a healthy living human into a walking corpse in less than fifteen seconds. It was originally kept as part of the Soviet Union's paraweapon stockpile by the KGB Division of Special Circumstances; its current whereabouts are unknown, and it may be in the hands of the criminal organization known as "Scarlet Hammer".

The thanatic source that caused the Chanhassen Catastrophe was not nearly that powerful. Originally recovered from the site of the Civil War Battle of Stones River, the Chanhassen source was a human femur from the body of Union Army Lieutenant Jeremiah Hackwell. It was engraved with an array of focusing sigils by the 19th-century scientist and necromancer Archibald Gravestone, one of the founders of Prometheus Labs, and further modified with inset silver circuitry by Prometheus Medical thanaturges. It was, as these things go, safe to be around; if undamaged, the Chanhassen source would take over a week of passive exposure to kill a healthy adult.

You will note that there are four variables in that sentence: "undamaged", "passive", "healthy" and "adult". We will come back to them later.

Chanhassen is an outer suburb on the southern edge of the Minneapolis-Saint Paul metropolitan area. It has a population of approximately twenty-five thousand, and is home to the Minnesota Landscape Arboretum; the Temple of Eck, headquarters of the new-age religious movement Eckankar; and Paisley Park, the former estate of the late musician Prince, now a recording studio and museum. It was also home to Athanasia Radiology, the Prometheus Medical subsidiary which conducted thanatotherapy trials in the 1970s.

Athanasia Radiology did not make it through the paratech crash, and shuttered its doors in 1997. All the mundane radiation sources were removed during the company's liquidation; Lieutenant Hackwell's femur was not. It remained untouched in a basement storage room for a quarter of a century, slightly lowering the life expectancy of the abandoned laboratory's rodent population and occasionally reanimating an insect. And there it would have stayed, if not for the intervention of a group of local teens.

On October 31st, 2023, around 10:30 PM, a group of six Chanhassen High School seniors broke in to the Athanasia Radiology facility on a dare. All the teenagers were mildly intoxicated, and two of them had smoked a small amount of cannabis. One of those two, Keith Dahl, had also consumed a dose of psilocybin mushrooms; unbeknownst to him, this psychedelic experience had awakened his latent thaumaturgic talent.

The ringleader, Mike Nelson, led the group into the basement, intending to hold a seance. The storage room containing the Chanhassen source was chosen, as it had the "spookiest vibes", and the teenagers soon found the source, deciding to use it as a prop for their seance. They lit candles, attempted to invoke the spirits of the dead, and passed around the femur. When Keith Dahl was given the femur, and called out to the spirit of its former owner, the Chanhassen Catastrophe began.

In the framework of Universal Thaumatology, there are three components to any thaumatological working (or, in layman's terms, a spell): energy, action, and will. Energy is given purpose by the caster's will and form by their action. Purpose guides form, leading to change. In the case of Keith Dahl's accidental working, the energy was the thanatic power of the Chanhassen source; the action was his invocation of Lieutenant Hackwell's spirit; and the will was his own desire to, in his own words, "see some spooky Halloween shit". The result of this malformed spell was predictably disastrous.

First: the summoning succeeded. Jeremiah Hackwell's shade was conjured up from Hell, the Tartarean realm where it had resided for the past 160 years. He was disoriented and only semi-sapient. This working had an approximate ARAD reading of 2.5 Kilocaspers, Sapphire, Sharp, Loose — moderate power, relatively blatant, constructive, and poorly formed. From these data, we can extrapolate the spell's backlash.

Lower intensity, opposite hue, opposite pitch, same weave. With a Loose weave, we expect backlash of around 75% the original intensity, or approximately 1.8 Kilocaspers. Hue goes from Sapphire to Lemon, reducing the blatancy of the effect; pitch goes from Sharp to Flat, resulting in a destructive effect. The Chanhassen source's inlaid circuitry was partially destroyed by a burst of heat, and as a result, the source began actively and uncontrollably emitting thanatic energy, killing and reanimating all six teenagers.

Secondary backlash occured with an intensity of about 1.25 Kilocaspers, and the same hue and pitch as the original spell. This bound the ghost of Jeremiah Hackwell into the Chanhassen source, and the ghost of Keith Dahl into his own reanimated corpse, allowing him to regain control of his body; the ghosts of the remaining teenagers were too weak to survive the binding, and dissipated.

Post-mortem sapience is possible for most thaumaturges, given sufficient study of the necromantic arts, but rarely desireable. Even the most powerful ghosts are limited by their existence as energy constructs, unable to work magic without destabilizing their animating essence and damaging their own memories. Revenants, like the unfortunate Mr. Dahl, are slightly hardier, and can safely cast spells using external EVE sources, but they require expensive chemical treatments and regular embalming sessions to stave off decay. Most mages simply prefer to die, and leave their legacy to their heirs.

Keith Dahl was luckier than most revenants, in that his body was in near-perfect condition; thanatic energy kills by interrupting metabolic processes, much like cyanide, leading to cell death without gross tissue damage. He had yet to realize that he was dead. His first reaction, upon regaining consciousness and seeing the corpses of his friends, was to call 911. The tertiary backlash (subtle, destructive) of his accidental spell had damaged his cell phone, but his friend Mary Anderson's was still functional, and he made the call. An ambulance was sent to the abandoned laboratory, followed by a Carver County sheriff's deputy.

Mr. Dahl made his way out of the basement to wait for emergency services, still holding the Chanhassen source. The ambulance arrived first, and the EMTs, Carlos Gutierrez and Julie Vang, quickly identified Mr. Dahl's lack of any vital signs. Given his continued animation, the human bone still clutched in his left hand, and the date, they decided to "get the fuck out before [they] got zombified too." They gave him a space blanket and a hand warmer, and fled the scene. This saved their lives.

Deputy Eli Johanssen was not so lucky. He had been warned about Mr. Dahl's undead nature by the paramedics, and came out of his squad car with his pistol drawn. Unfortunately, Carver County sheriff's uniforms are grey, and Jeremiah Hackwell's bound spirit was startled. Believing Deputy Johanssen to be a member of the Confederate Army, Hackwell used his nascent control over the Chanhassen source to shoot a focused beam of thanatic energy at Deputy Johanssen's heart, killing him instantly.

At this point, Mr. Dahl fled back into the abandoned laboratory with the Chanhassen source. His decision to hide, rather than to make his way into town in search of medical attention or an authority figure, likely saved many lives. Within two hours, alerted by keywords in local law enforcement radio transmissions, Moblie Task Force Psi-8 ("The Silencers") had arrived on the scene, and quickly contained Mr. Dahl and the Chanhassen source.

At his request, Mr. Dahl's spirit was banished after a brief interview; his body and the bodies of his friends were deanimated and returned to their families for burial. Standard cover story CO-3, "Carbon Monoxide Inhalation," was disseminated to the press. The EMTs, Mr. Gutierrez and Ms. Vang, were amnesticized and implanted with false memories of discovering the bodies of the children and the sheriff's deputy in the laboratory basement. The Chanhassen source is classified as SCP-█████, and is contained in a lead-lined containment locker at Storage Site-23.

There are three primary lessons to be learned from the Chanhassen Catastrophe.

First, that paratechnology must be contained. If the Athanasia Radiology clinic had been located in a paranormal enclave such as Three Portlands, it is likely that the Chanhassen Source would not have been abandoned in the first place; and if it had, anyone who encountered it would have been better equipped to recognize it as a dangerous occult artifact. The spread of paratechnology into unveiled society is dangerous, and preventing that spread is one of the primary purposes of the Foundation; nexuses and freeports are the lesser of two evils.

Second, that thaumatology is inherently dangerous. Even operatives of the Global Occult Coalition sometimes fail to sufficiently account for backlash; if the best-trained occultists in the world can be killed by an unmanaged spell, self-trained civilian thaumaturges stand no chance. The Coalition's near-monopoly on thaumatological education probably causes more good than harm, at least for now, but the Foundation, in the interest of public safety and the continuity of humanity, has a duty to contain or eliminate any thaumaturges not affiliated with the GOC.

And finally, that civilian cowardice saves lives. The EMTs immediately left the scene when they realized that Mr. Dahl's condition was anomalous; after the death of Deputy Johanssen, Mr. Dahl himself hid from further human contact. Both these actions prevented deaths, and more could have been prevented if Mr. Dahl and his friends had been too scared to enter the abandoned laboratory in the first place. Foundation social engineering programs since the end of the Cold War have done an admirable job at maintaining high levels of fear and anxiety in the American populace, and consistently prove their worth; if adolescent male bravado can be further tempered, it is estimated that civilian contact with the anomalous could be reduced by up to 15%. A scared populace is a quiet populace.

dig-u-better-dead.raw_source: [[include component:preview text=An "orphan source" is a radiation source no longer under regulatory control, usually because it has been lost, stolen or abandoned.]] [[include :scp-wiki:theme:3law]] [[>]] [[module Rate]] [[/>]] Thanatotherapy was developed in the 1960s by Prometheus Medical, one of the many subsidiaries of Prometheus Labs. A novel treatment for certain cancers, thanatotherapeutic techniques involve the targeted application of thanatic energy (also marketed as "omega radiation") to cancerous tissues. Unlike ionizing radiation, thanatic energy can be modified by a skilled thanaturge or necromancer to only damage cancer cells, leaving healthy tissues unharmed; Prometheus Medical cured dozens of previously-terminal patients in clinical trials, and in '72 they were getting ready for a full commercial roll-out. Then the first patient died. And then they came back. Thanatotherapy was shelved shortly after that. Spontaneous reanimation is bad optics, and mundane radiation oncology was catching up pretty quickly. The labs were mothballed, and the equipment put into storage. And there it would have sat, safely locked away, if not for the paratech crash and the subsequent breakup of Prometheus Labs. ----- An "orphan source" is a radiation source no longer under regulatory control, usually because it has been lost, stolen or abandoned. The most serious orphan source incident in mundane history was the Goiânia accident, which occurred when a cesium-137 radiation source was stolen from an abandoned radiotherapy clinic in Brazil; four people died, and two hundred and fifty were exposed to significant levels of radiation. The Chanhassen Catastrophe claimed more lives in the first thirty seconds. ----- Ionizing radiation sources are all, broadly speaking, the same. You need a radioactive isotope; you need a container to hold it; you need shielding around that container. Every source of thanatic energy is different. They are born from tragedies, hundreds or thousands of deaths at the same place or time; the only attempts to systematize their creation have been prosecuted as crimes against humanity. They are not as rare as one would hope. Nearly every battle of the Second World War created a thanatic source, the death-energy concentrating around a particular totem: an officer's ancestral katana, a tank crew's lucky charm, or a particularly bloodthirsty general's corn-cob pipe. The same goes for the First: a blasted tree in no-man's-land, or the perforated skull of the first casualty. Before those were the Opium Wars, the Napoleonic Wars, the Wars of the Reformation; and after, Korea, Vietnam, the Congo. Humans are good at killing each other. ----- The most powerful thanatic source known to modern thaumatologists (excluding Mythic Age creations like the Atlantean Dead Mind) is the Volga Core, a roughly skull-shaped piece of furnace slag recovered from the ruins of the Red October steel plant after the Battle of Stalingrad. Exposure to the Volga Core can turn a healthy living human into a walking corpse in less than fifteen seconds. It was originally kept as part of the Soviet Union's paraweapon stockpile by the KGB Division of Special Circumstances; its current whereabouts are unknown, and it may be in the hands of the criminal organization known as "Scarlet Hammer". The thanatic source that caused the Chanhassen Catastrophe was not nearly that powerful. Originally recovered from the site of the Civil War Battle of Stones River, the Chanhassen source was a human femur from the body of Union Army Lieutenant Jeremiah Hackwell. It was engraved with an array of focusing sigils by the 19th-century scientist and necromancer Archibald Gravestone, one of the founders of Prometheus Labs, and further modified with inset silver circuitry by Prometheus Medical thanaturges. It was, as these things go, safe to be around; if undamaged, the Chanhassen source would take over a week of passive exposure to kill a healthy adult. You will note that there are four variables in that sentence: "undamaged", "passive", "healthy" and "adult". We will come back to them later. ----- Chanhassen is an outer suburb on the southern edge of the Minneapolis-Saint Paul metropolitan area. It has a population of approximately twenty-five thousand, and is home to the Minnesota Landscape Arboretum; the Temple of Eck, headquarters of the new-age religious movement Eckankar; and Paisley Park, the former estate of the late musician Prince, now a recording studio and museum. It was also home to Athanasia Radiology, the Prometheus Medical subsidiary which conducted thanatotherapy trials in the 1970s. Athanasia Radiology did not make it through the paratech crash, and shuttered its doors in 1997. All the mundane radiation sources were removed during the company's liquidation; Lieutenant Hackwell's femur was not. It remained untouched in a basement storage room for a quarter of a century, slightly lowering the life expectancy of the abandoned laboratory's rodent population and occasionally reanimating an insect. And there it would have stayed, if not for the intervention of a group of local teens. ----- On October 31st, 2023, around 10:30 PM, a group of six Chanhassen High School seniors broke in to the Athanasia Radiology facility on a dare. All the teenagers were mildly intoxicated, and two of them had smoked a small amount of cannabis. One of those two, Keith Dahl, had also consumed a dose of psilocybin mushrooms; unbeknownst to him, this psychedelic experience had awakened his latent thaumaturgic talent. The ringleader, Mike Nelson, led the group into the basement, intending to hold a seance. The storage room containing the Chanhassen source was chosen, as it had the "spookiest vibes", and the teenagers soon found the source, deciding to use it as a prop for their seance. They lit candles, attempted to invoke the spirits of the dead, and passed around the femur. When Keith Dahl was given the femur, and called out to the spirit of its former owner, the Chanhassen Catastrophe began. ----- In the framework of Universal Thaumatology, there are three components to any thaumatological working (or, in layman's terms, a spell): energy, action, and will. Energy is given purpose by the caster's will and form by their action. Purpose guides form, leading to change. In the case of Keith Dahl's accidental working, the energy was the thanatic power of the Chanhassen source; the action was his invocation of Lieutenant Hackwell's spirit; and the will was his own desire to, in his own words, "see some spooky Halloween shit". The result of this malformed spell was predictably disastrous. First: the summoning succeeded. Jeremiah Hackwell's shade was conjured up from Hell, the Tartarean realm where it had resided for the past 160 years. He was disoriented and only semi-sapient. This working had an approximate ARAD reading of 2.5 Kilocaspers, Sapphire, Sharp, Loose -- moderate power, relatively blatant, constructive, and poorly formed. From these data, we can extrapolate the spell's backlash. Lower intensity, opposite hue, opposite pitch, same weave. With a Loose weave, we expect backlash of around 75% the original intensity, or approximately 1.8 Kilocaspers. Hue goes from Sapphire to Lemon, reducing the blatancy of the effect; pitch goes from Sharp to Flat, resulting in a destructive effect. The Chanhassen source's inlaid circuitry was partially destroyed by a burst of heat, and as a result, the source began actively and uncontrollably emitting thanatic energy, killing and reanimating all six teenagers. Secondary backlash occured with an intensity of about 1.25 Kilocaspers, and the same hue and pitch as the original spell. This bound the ghost of Jeremiah Hackwell into the Chanhassen source, and the ghost of Keith Dahl into his own reanimated corpse, allowing him to regain control of his body; the ghosts of the remaining teenagers were too weak to survive the binding, and dissipated. ----- Post-mortem sapience is possible for most thaumaturges, given sufficient study of the necromantic arts, but rarely desireable. Even the most powerful ghosts are limited by their existence as energy constructs, unable to work magic without destabilizing their animating essence and damaging their own memories. Revenants, like the unfortunate Mr. Dahl, are slightly hardier, and can safely cast spells using external EVE sources, but they require expensive chemical treatments and regular embalming sessions to stave off decay. Most mages simply prefer to die, and leave their legacy to their heirs. Keith Dahl was luckier than most revenants, in that his body was in near-perfect condition; thanatic energy kills by interrupting metabolic processes, much like cyanide, leading to cell death without gross tissue damage. He had yet to realize that he was dead. His first reaction, upon regaining consciousness and seeing the corpses of his friends, was to call 911. The tertiary backlash (subtle, destructive) of his accidental spell had damaged his cell phone, but his friend Mary Anderson's was still functional, and he made the call. An ambulance was sent to the abandoned laboratory, followed by a Carver County sheriff's deputy. ----- Mr. Dahl made his way out of the basement to wait for emergency services, still holding the Chanhassen source. The ambulance arrived first, and the EMTs, Carlos Gutierrez and Julie Vang, quickly identified Mr. Dahl's lack of any vital signs. Given his continued animation, the human bone still clutched in his left hand, and the date, they decided to "get the fuck out before [they] got zombified too." They gave him a space blanket and a hand warmer, and fled the scene. This saved their lives. Deputy Eli Johanssen was not so lucky. He had been warned about Mr. Dahl's undead nature by the paramedics, and came out of his squad car with his pistol drawn. Unfortunately, Carver County sheriff's uniforms are grey, and Jeremiah Hackwell's bound spirit was startled. Believing Deputy Johanssen to be a member of the Confederate Army, Hackwell used his nascent control over the Chanhassen source to shoot a focused beam of thanatic energy at Deputy Johanssen's heart, killing him instantly. At this point, Mr. Dahl fled back into the abandoned laboratory with the Chanhassen source. His decision to hide, rather than to make his way into town in search of medical attention or an authority figure, likely saved many lives. Within two hours, alerted by keywords in local law enforcement radio transmissions, Moblie Task Force Psi-8 ("The Silencers") had arrived on the scene, and quickly contained Mr. Dahl and the Chanhassen source. At his request, Mr. Dahl's spirit was banished after a brief interview; his body and the bodies of his friends were deanimated and returned to their families for burial. Standard cover story CO-3, "Carbon Monoxide Inhalation," was disseminated to the press. The EMTs, Mr. Gutierrez and Ms. Vang, were amnesticized and implanted with false memories of discovering the bodies of the children and the sheriff's deputy in the laboratory basement. First, that paratechnology must be contained. If the Athanasia Radiology clinic had been located in a paranormal enclave such as Three Portlands, it is likely that the Chanhassen Source would not have been abandoned in the first place; and if it had, anyone who encountered it would have been better equipped to recognize it as a dangerous occult artifact. The spread of paratechnology into unveiled society is dangerous, and preventing that spread is one of the primary purposes of the Foundation; nexuses and freeports are the lesser of two evils. Second, that thaumatology is inherently dangerous. Even operatives of the Global Occult Coalition sometimes fail to sufficiently account for backlash; if the best-trained occultists in the world can be killed by an unmanaged spell, self-trained civilian thaumaturges stand no chance. The Coalition's near-monopoly on thaumatological education probably causes more good than harm, at least for now, but the Foundation, in the interest of public safety and the continuity of humanity, has a duty to contain or eliminate any thaumaturges not affiliated with the GOC. And finally, that civilian cowardice saves lives. Both these actions prevented deaths, and more could have been prevented if Mr. Dahl and his friends had been too scared to enter the abandoned laboratory in the first place. down-the-tracks.raw_content:
crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 01:03:29 #83920137

Hello Parawatchers. Recently, my roommate returned from his trip to England. While there, he visited the old town of Millwood, which was abandoned in the 1890s. I didn't think much of it at first, until I asked why. Although he claimed it was due to safety reasons, I believe otherwise.

Something about it didn't sit right with me, a town with 231 people wouldn't just up and leave because of "safety concerns". I started looking into it, and there was more. I've found not one, but two cold cases. While these people disappeared on different days, I believe both are connected. Not only to each other, but to Millwood's abandonment.

crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 01:35:06 #83921489

In the 1890s, Millwood was struggling financially. Newspapers from the time reported high rates of unemployment, with businesses often closing. In hopes of improving the economy, construction for Millwood Station would be approved by the town mayor and begin on November 13th, 1893.

The working conditions were undoubtedly hazardous, but supposedly nothing occurred. Despite this, a lot of employees building Millwood station often left the project. But why?

Charles Walker, an American, played the leading role during construction, having been in the industry for about twenty years. People knew him for one of two things: his short temper, and working his employees to the bone. In one particular account, Charles dismissed an employee following a disagreement over work hours.

The Millwood Station was originally scheduled to open on May 21st, 1894. Due to the high employee turnover, it wouldn't open until August 3rd, 1894. Despite this delay, the town of Millwood welcomed their new train station with open arms and a celebration. While the station boosted the town's economy, this prosperity would be short-lived.

crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 02:10:21 #83921963

On August 10th, 1894, a week after the Millwood Station’s opening, Charles would begin to exhibit odd behaviors that were unusual even for him. According to the residents, he would lock himself in his house during the day, never coming out even for groceries. In a journal entry, a railroad officer claimed to have seen him wandering near the station at night.

Charles would go missing briefly from September 21st until October 5th of the same year, when he arrived at Millwood's police station. There, Arthur Moore, the town's detective, took him for a brief statement.

Listen here, you can make fun of me all you want. I don't care what you or anyone else in this town thinks of me. But heed my warning, don't follow the tracks. If you do, may God have mercy on you.

After further questioning, Arthur would release Charles from police custody. He would go missing again three days later on October 8th, 1894. This time, Charles would never return, and here's where it gets interesting. Just a week later, on October 15th, Arthur stopped showing up to work.

crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 02:45:59 #83921021

In a letter addressed to his sister, according to his wife, Arthur didn’t isolate himself in his home. Unlike Charles, Arthur would always be near the train tracks no matter the time of day. He never had a notepad, pen, or even the tobacco pipe he always carried around. Arthur would walk by the railroad, whistling for no purpose or cause.

Despite his wife’s efforts to return him home, Arthur would always go back to Millwood Station. He would then go missing on, November 3rd, 1894 and never be seen again. It was around this time people started to leave Millwood.

Today, the town of Millwood and its railroad station remains as a historical site. Despite its evacuation, based on images, everything appears to be untouched. My roommate claimed it’s like they never left.

On their website, the owners of the area dismiss these claims as rumors and have closed their reviews. However, according to multiple feedback sites, people claim to hear whistling down the tracks.
