girlraisingproject.raw_source: [[include :scp-wiki:theme:black-highlighter-theme]] [[include :scp-wiki:theme:vanguard |dark=--] ]] [[include :scp-wiki:info:start]] [[span style="color:white"]]**Author:**[[/span]] [[*user whenwerewe]] [*https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/whenwerewe Here's my page!] [[span style="color:white"]]warning for child death in moderate detail and enormous quantity of body-horror[[/span]] [[include :scp-wiki:info:end]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:info-cw]] @@ @@ The second time I was born, I clutched my daughter in my arms. I held the whole world away from her with my hands and my ribs and my skull. Three spears were thrust into my back, and a fourth into the neck had killed me. While I was dead, the fifth had taken her, too. As I blearily cracked open my eyes, already stiffening with rigor mortis, she trembled beside me. Her last breath was drowned out by bickering. Behind, the men who had killed us argued loudly in a foreign tongue about what to do next. The tallest of them, disfigured by a twisted arm and muscles like an ox, gestured violently towards the hills we’d descended from. Perhaps some of my band had escaped. It was bitter comfort to me now. I rose slowly to my feet. I held her by the wrist as I had so many times before, and she fell limply by the arm beside me. She was too light. What? Oh. I’ve never had one of you try to //comfort// me before. That was a long time ago, anyway. The mud-brick village we had tried to raid was not yet called Uruk, and the men were not yet the Sumerians. Even the pale and weedy grass they gnawed at was not yet really wheat. They were a stunted lot, and might have been pitiable if they hadn’t taken my daughter. Don’t look at me like that. We were starving. They had been pushing us out of the plains and into the high valleys all my life. Not that any of this matters. I’m beyond trying to claw at the //moral high ground//. My fellows were scattered around me, dead to the last. We didn’t know how to fight their numbers, their corded slings and taut bows, their weapons of strange and shining stone. They’d died so easily. So I woke them up. One by one the dead rose. Seized joints cracked with unexpected flexion, tendon and sinew hesitantly peeled apart. Their blood pooled thickly at their feet. The men turned around to look at me, and them. Their faces were portraits of dread. When I have trouble sleeping I think of them and drift off. Then -- there was all the tedious struggle, and all the tedious begging. But I had them in the end. One made it two hours down the packed dirt path that was not yet the world’s first road, throwing his brothers behind him, in cowardice or appeasement. And there was my daughter. I carried her all the way. She was slight, and stiff, and as the sun set she began to cool until by touch I could not distinguish her from the earth in which I lay her. There is nothing pretty about the dead, no matter what the fanatics say. They’ll rant at you as long as you care to listen, about beauty, certainty, symmetry. They’re just insane; anyone who would do this is, really. I was ready to leave the meat of my daughter in the earth. But just before I did, something rose out of her, that was not breath, and clung to me. I thought I might as well keep it around. At the time I didn’t let myself think something so stupid, but it would be nice to have her back. Yes, that’s why I’m doing this, obviously. It’s always nice to have perceptive material. But try not to yell too much, it strains the diaphragm; you’ll want that nice and fresh for later. I had lost other children, of course. You think of it as the ultimate tragedy. None of you can guess how lucky you are. Even just three centuries ago… it was something mothers expected. Which is not to say that it was ever easy. I would have called all of them back to life, if I could. But only her soul remained to me, and I am less sentimental about these things than most. Mhm. Still sentimental enough to cut you up. Oh? Well, this is the last time you’ll be able to speak for a while, so I might as well. Once, when I was the same age my daughter was when she died, I ran into a leprous hundred-headed snake. Not that any of us knew what leprosy was in those days. But its skin was peeling and ulcerating; great blisters and cancers riddled every inch of exposed muscle; its eyes were spasming as it begged me for a drop of blood. And because I was young and stupid, I cut open my palm with a flint and let it drink, and it skittered off, begging me not to speak of its appearance to anyone. When three days later I ran into two beautiful men, fire-skinned and stinking of what I now realise must have been incense, I told them everything they asked me. They laughed in a voice like cracking ice and promised me their Queen’s blessing. That probably had something to do with it. It now occurs to me they were definitely Mab’s. I think I took a side in their civil war by doing that. I had a lot of headaches over the topic, later. Anyway, that’s where it began. Now, nod if you’d rather be blind for this next bit. [[include :scp-wiki:component:wide-image-sizer]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:image-block name=http://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/local--files/girlraisingproject/goat.jpg | caption=We have both been reshaped by men. This sweet little thing is nothing like the huge beasts I knew in my youth. It became domestic; I went the other way. My dead razed village and town for generations, made me the enemy of all the settled peoples. But I returned to the ruins to find five more sprouting. I simply could not keep up. So when they offered me copper and iron, which I barely understood, I accepted. When they showed me the strange shapes they’d carved into their clay, I learned. And I found that I had a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ereshkigal new name]. | align=center | width=100% ]] ----- @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ There. That wasn’t so bad, was it? Just a little joke! I don’t get to talk to a lot of people. If you try to be funny near a Karcist they look at you like you’re an alien. Really, though, you’ll be fine. The vertebra fused back into place; you’re practically good as new. Look, just don’t pay attention to the lathe. No, no, if you keep panicking yourself like that I’ll have to paralyse you again. Just think about something else. This really shouldn’t be hurting that much. Do you want to hear more about me? I’ll take that as a yes. It was during the Hussite Wars-- Stop looking confused, they weren’t occult. You people just don’t know anything about your ancestors these days. I’d be angry if I hadn’t known how worthless they were personally. This was around the fourteen-hundreds. Is that good enough for you? Don’t wail or I’ll block your trachea. Thank you. Now, as I was saying, I was searching for a fleshsmith. This is skipping millennia of my life, but they weren’t very //dense// millennia. Fill in about six hours of me narrating executions of uncouth men on the road, if you want. I had come to Esterberg, the hidden city. In those days there were far less humans, and many more faeries, and those odd ape-things. It stank like dead fish and liceridden fur. The city, like all cities in those days, was an open sore in the world. But it was the only place I could find someone who could stitch my daughter’s soul back into a body. Yes, despite ten thousand years of wandering, I did not exactly have my finger on the pulse of the occult world (what a hilarious expression!). I had brushed up against the edges of Fae activity -- and immediately fled -- and I had run into fleshcarves and cogkindred on the road or in the hovels the peasants gave me in return for their lives. But I was only vaguely aware of, for example, the existence of the Daevites. It does not help that I did not hold, and indeed still do not hold, with cities. I can tolerate a thousand people living together, but once you start to lose count that’s a bad sign. Sorry, this is besides the point. The tendonwork is distracting me. There, you should be able to speak again. Now, where was I? I had found after endless searching a suitable fleshcrafter, brought him my daughter’s soul and a spare girl-child, and after deploying enough threats I was sure he wouldn’t simply dispose of her errant spirit I set out into the city. I wanted to see if I could find some useful contacts, perhaps some tips on the location of other nexuses. To my later dismay, it turned out the city was quite firmly antiroyalist territory. And you know how Fae get; they just have this way about them. They learn things they have no right knowing. So I walked into the square with my retinue-- I kept about two dozen of the dead with me at all times. Had them in low-brimmed hats, big cloaks, stuffed them with herbs and so on. Mostly I got away with claiming to be a wandering priestess, though it didn’t work in Esterberg, of course. In the square there was an eyeless beggar. And by eyeless I mean great divots had been sunk all over his bared skin, so you could see the half a hundred weeping sockets that must have once seen unimaginable sights. When I walked past him, he pointed straight at me. Every single face in the square turned to stare right at me within three seconds. Now, you understand, I was in what is today Poland. I had been born near Iraq. I was //used// to standing out. It wasn’t anything like today, obviously, but I got little stares, kids either knew I was the funniest thing around or squealed when they saw me, you get the idea. They thought I was a Turk, which got a laugh the first time they said it to my face. What it felt like when that entire square, probably five thousand people, turned to bore into my head? I cannot describe it. I barely heard what the beggar said next. Something about crimes revealed and reconciled, a trial before the House of the Inventor, pardon-by-years. I couldn’t really pay attention to the words while everyone looked at me. Blank and confident, like men who hold shining stars in their hands, and know that not only can you not save yourself, you cannot save //anyone//. So, yes, I admit it, I panicked. I ordered my dead to lash out and fled in the terror. Anyone who died I raised too, to buy me my hour. It turns out that for all their staring most of the people in the square were basically civilians. And two dozen doesn’t sound like many, but if they don’t die when you kill them they can do a lot. So today I think they have a little plaque where the beggar used to sit, for the thanatotic riot of 1433. Killed about eight hundred, supposedly. While the citizens ran about like headless chickens I collected my project and dispatched the uncooperative Karcist with my favourite trick. That was the fifty-seventh time I died. I fled the city with her in my arms, all my dead lost to its militia, the happiest I’d been in centuries. To call back a soul, well-formed, from //millenia// of sleep? Every two-bit reanimator called it impossible. Oh, come on, you know me better than that. I wouldn’t do this to you for //fun//; I’m not such a sadist I’d risk the Coalition’s wrath. Obviously something didn’t work out. My daughter woke up. Her flesh was as cold as mine, but that was no burden. She would never be hungry again, and if she ever left me I knew I could bring her back. I would try to teach her, somehow, and let her do the same to me. We would pass through the ages of man together. That was the first time I really thought about my power, in detail. Yes, try and pull what remains of your face into a smirk, very classy. I was raised when the cutting edge of technology was //writing//. It took me fully three thousand years to realise the priests of Ashur and Marduk could not literally talk to the gods. I had to essentially invent the entire notion of necromancy from scratch. Well, thank you! But of course I don’t seem that old. If I did, I would have gone insane a very long time ago. Can you imagine what it feels like for me to see a warhorse, an automobile, a spacecraft? Wait, wait, sorry. I’m letting you rile me up. Back to the story. My daughter was the child I’d loved, in every detail. Exactly every detail. She did not gain new traits, or lose old ones. It was as if her soul was frozen in amber. Something about the way it connected to her newly-conquered flesh was defective. She could puppeteer the body, but the body could not embed memories in her being. So she remembered only the last month, at best. She is an eternal youth, and can never grow. For a while, I thought her perfect as she was. Though I had not known it, this had been what I was missing all those empty years. The two of us lived out the Thirty Years’ War in an obscure hut, mother and child (much later did we learn this was also the //Fifth// Occult War). I taught her a hundred times, to weave, to write, to feel safe. She did not feel an empty belly even once, and occasionally I entertained her by dismembering lost //landsknechte//. But I couldn’t stay satisfied forever. Every mother wants to see her daughter grow into herself. She should have been my equal, and risen a queen of the dead alongside me. We would resurrect each other cyclically, until the last city fell. You people never fail to irritate me. No, don’t flinch, just -- if you want to ask something, //ask it//! What’s the point of this ridiculous “May I ask” nonsense? It’s not as if tiptoeing around will make me any more merciful. Oh. You want to know //that//, do you. Why do I tell these stories in such varying tones. Why am I so cavalier about everything except my daughter. How insightful. You know, I don’t think you’re being totally //sincere// in your questioning. I think you’re trying to make some sort of //point//. Perhaps to imply a false and saccharine equivalence between her and //other// people. So let me answer your question with a question of my own: what do you think happens if you supercharge a person’s amygdala for five minutes? Do they just have a heart attack? Let’s find out, shall we? [[include :scp-wiki:component:wide-image-sizer]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:image-block name=http://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/local--files/girlraisingproject/woods.jpg | caption=I have had no small number of encounters with [[span style="color:green"]]the abode of quiet[[/span]]. However, I dare only the shallows, for fear of what might wait for me where the sun does not reach. They say the survivors of the Queen’s wrath fled there, and perhaps some wait for me still, growing old and hungry. | align=center | width=100% ]] ----- @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ It’s alright, words can be hard after going through that. I mean, empirically. I haven’t experienced it myself. Now, good news. This next part will actually be totally painless! I’m going to anaesthetise you. It might also scramble your internal body-model, though. It’ll give you, what’s the word? Dysphoria? A shot of that, real concentrated, but over quick. That expression there is… Let me tell you another story. This one might even give you context on what’s happening to you. Concentrate on the words, please. So I was in Chernobyl-- Oh, alright, fine. I’d spent the past three hundred years looking for someone who knew how to help my daughter’s situation. Well, I say that, but it’s not strictly true. I spent fifty years searching, and then I realised I’d have to do it myself. I learnt at the feet of the great soul-sages; I did favours for children of the Scarlet Fool; I even managed to win a lesson off one of the Wild Hunt on a bet. I began to put together something like a //theory// of necromancy. I was inspired by what was in the air in those days. All those philosophers, those men of science! There was something romantic about the idea the world could be understood. I knew firsthand it was false, of course. So I set out on a course of experimentation. That’s when I began collecting material in earnest, and yes, that’s why you’re in here, you poor thing. Anyway, as I said, I was in Chernobyl. After the Russians cursed the land, they evacuated the whole town. The margins of error for that kind of thing are large enough to lose a lot of people. Ripe pickings for little old me. What do you mean “talk like that”? I talk like //myself//. If I wasn’t able to change with the times I would have lost my mind a long time ago. Even last century, there was barely such a thing as a Foundation, and now they’ve fallen apart. If I adapted any slower the pace of events would overtake me, you understand? Right, so, outskirts of Chernobyl, going shopping for new material. I couldn’t bring my dead everywhere, the way I used to. The stink was too obvious, the scarves and hats too blatant. There were cameras metastasising on every street corner. I had to struggle just to carry one or two along with me those days. So there I was, walking around in a ridiculous coat and sunglasses, dragging this briefcase by my side. My daughter was never the type to cling to my skirts. She was away somewhere in the city. It wouldn’t do to spend all my time worrying about her survival, so in the past hundred years I’d fit her with a few extra features. If you are about to call me a bad parent, then be warned that I might start trying to be a good one, //starting with my research efforts//. No? Excellent. I’d had my fair share of encounters with what are now hilariously called “normalcy preservation organisations”. Bloodless and wretched things. They’d tried to chain my daughter more times than I can count. I could accept that they’d come after me, but she was just a slip of a girl. Their cruelty knew no bounds. One moment I was walking down an emptying street, and the next three agents leapt out from a decrepit old house and blew a neat triplet of holes in my torso. Of course by this point I was really quite hard to kill, but the three of them were backed up by two brutes in hazmat armour. They caught me about the neck with a loop of rope like some kind of animal and emptied their magazines. I was still conscious, but there’s not really a lot you can do with gaping holes in every major muscle group. They dragged me into the base they’d set up in their shack, which inside was done up like some kind of watchpost. I recognised vaguely the equipment and the general style: they were with Her Majesty's Foundation for the Secure Containment of the Paranormal, or one of its descendants. This-- It was the worst I’ve ever felt. Even the day I lost my daughter, there was a kind of lingering apathy. I let the waves wash over me until my head only rarely broke the surface, and I almost forgot what loss was at all. This wasn’t like that. They were right there, in the room with me, and I couldn’t move. She was out there, waiting for me, and when she came to find me, and she found //them//, and I would have to watch, if she found them would they even capture her or just pulp her fucking brain again-- Oops! Sorry. It’ll reattach, don’t worry. And anyway, you’re not going to miss it for long. Hmph. Suffice to say I wasn’t feeling great. They put me in cuffs, and were preparing some kind of sedative, which might even have worked. But… One of them had taken //my briefcase//. And you know how they are. Their type just cannot stand an unanswered question. I don’t know who they thought I was. If they’d known exactly who they’d found they would have burned it. But instead poor idiot mister Foundation popped the locks. The layers of the dermis aren’t actually connected very strongly, you know? Once you puncture the membrane somewhere, you can work your way through the subcutaneous tissue pretty easy. Especially if you’re using, say, human jaws. He reeled back and half his face was missing, torn off by the thing in the case. He screamed -- I think he was trying to cry for help, but it had gotten into his muscles, too -- and the rest of the agents opened up on my poor valiant servant. Then she arrived. Must have tracked her mother by scent, or perhaps she was playing stalk-and-catch. I was so proud of her. Just walked in through the front door, quiet as could be. I think the field team were a little off kilter for some reason, so they didn’t shoot her. One of them screamed at her to get back while the other three tried to wrangle my homunculus. He actually ran over and tried to grab her and get out of the house! Well, my daughter popped his head off, of course. Then they turned their attention to her properly, but now there were only three of them against two of my dead and my dear girl. It was quick, and then it was slow. Two of them surrendered. I was worried they’d hurt her, but she was only superficially perforated. At worst it was inconvenient. I’d have to reattach her spinal cord where a stray round had pierced it to get her lower body functional again, that was all. As soon as I broke my restraints I embraced her and praised her for that display of  bravery. We left at once, with the two captives restrained and lugged with us. One of them begged us the whole way to release his subordinate. I told him I’d do his job for him and reprimand her and he made such a noise. It was a great pick-me-up after everything. When we got back I scrapped him for parts -- in fact, look back there, you can still see his spine wriggling in the pneumatitrator! Isn’t it kind of cute? No? Oh, be sullen, then. When my daughter gets like this I give her a chocolate and some leftovers, but I suspect that wouldn’t work on you. I would have found somewhere for his inferior to make herself useful, too, but it turned out the paralytic had made its way to her lungs. Ho hum. He did get his wish; that was my good deed for the decade. Afterwards I took the kid out for a treat. Blue steak in Lyon. And, oh dear, speaking of hypoxia I do think your airway is blocked. Why didn’t you //say// any-- Right, you don’t have an isolation chamber for your larynx. My bad. Can you hear me right now? Were you even conscious for the back half of my story? It’s awfully rude of you to choke on your blood while I was doing all this helpful work on your intestines, and I shall have my recompense, I say. Ha. Oh, what a mess. I can’t get another one of you, it’d be such a headache. I hope you can tolerate a little brain damage. [[include :scp-wiki:component:wide-image-sizer]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:image-block name=http://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/local--files/girlraisingproject/ruin.webp | caption=The cities played at worship, but the only thing they truly cared for was counting. They loved measure and tabulation more than their own children. So when I saw them leave an an entire city behind with no hesitation, I knew things were serious. It was a rich age for me and mine. | align=center | width=100% ]] ----- @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ @@ Are you back? Hm? Oh, the slurring isn’t too bad. I was worried I’d rendered you incogent. Monologuing is only fun with a lucid audience. Well, that episode wasn’t all that interesting, regardless. I was just explaining how much I love my daughter, indulging in my motherly urges and so on. I know //you types// aren’t a fan. What? Strike a nerve? Hm. You’ve gone soft in your old age, regardless. No, not -- don’t look at me like that. Yes, you’re very young, and I’m sure that hair is attractive to… somebody. But //you//, the Foundation, whatever you call yourselves nowadays. What you’ve been getting up to is positively pathetic. The other day I heard a “Vanguard” pharmacy put out a call for vampires to come in for conditioning treatment! Did you get so lazy you decided you’d try and get all your enemies to just go willingly to their dissection and death? If even one of the daughters of the great Impaler appeared I’d eat my shoes. I can’t hear you; the nerve damage has really got to your tongue. Try harder. Listen, I like to joke with the material, but that’s ridiculous. If you want to tell me a lie, make it believable. You’re so awful at subterfuge I’m probably doing good by increasing the competence of your agency. No, come on, this persistence is pathetic. Even if you did somehow hoodwink //ten// bloodsuckers into showing up, you don’t need to keep up this pretense about, what do you call it, “harm reduction”, around //me//. Look at me! I’m not going to judge you if you admit you scattered their ashes in the river. I have to respect your commitment. Maybe you even believe it. The Foundation were always masters of self-deception. I thought Vanguard had turned a new leaf. This has been an educational exchange for the //both// of us. Ah, but their new era has not been without its upsides. I am a great appreciator of your people’s  newfound openmindedness. If they’d adopted this attitude from the start, we’d all be deathless by now. To think of how much easier things would have been if they hadn’t clung to their idiot notions… I could strangle those pitiful Overseers. Still, I didn’t say no to the amnesty when they offered it. Oh, you look like a kicked puppy. Yes, one of their liaisons offered me a pardon if I’d agree to test on their mimicflesh and swear off the good stuff. I did try it for a few months, but it’s just not the same. There are all these obscure occult properties, and the mimics don’t even scream properly. Yes, and that’s you caught up to the modern day, more or less. I skipped over a variety of encounters with dullards who thought they’d be the one to kill me, but nothing worth telling. I absolutely //do// have to do this. My daughter’s memory is up to a nice round two years, which is about ten thousand short of what I’ll accept. Oh, good job on the smile! I thought your zygomaticus was halfway to necrosis, congratulations. Can I ask what brought it on? Would it have anything to do with the dozen Coalition jackboots fumbling out of their base toward my pretty little abode? You remain an awful liar, dear. Of course you know what I’m talking about. You called them here with that goetic beacon in your pericardial cavity. Or maybe not; the world is full of coincidences. And there goes the grin. It’s a shame, it looks good on you. Really shows off your incisors. I think those will be your main input into my next project. Every single sneering warden thinks they have me pegged. Here’s a doddering old lady from before we invented writing, who’s escaped capture by slinking away from everything dangerous, burdened by an imbecile daughter barely capable of feeding herself. I’ve seen what you write about me. You have such interesting //opinions// about my work. And even though I have slipped through the nets of a hundred generations, every two-bit Director is just so sure he’ll be the one to bring this antique into the reliquary that is her rightful place. Chernobyl was the closest you ever came, and you were still //pretty damn far//. I told you: if I could not adapt to the world as it is, I would have gone mad eons ago. And yet every time one of your technicians invent some new gimmick you try to catch me with it. The Scythians tried riding me down with their precious cavalry, old Rameses had a go with chariots, Metternich cornered me with grenadiers, De Gaulle’s goons poisoned me with some fancy paralytic. All of them are decorating the east wall of the lab, now. Don’t look! I just said I want your teeth, and the vomit does terrible things to the enamel. And your precious Coalition, with their newest hack. These unbinding mechanists have made a right mess. You know a month ago, the thrall they were interviewing on TV, where they had to keep redacting segments of her life story because her master was a wanted criminal? That was //me//! I mean, the embarrassment I felt, I just wanted a hole to open up and swallow her. Having my reputation tarnished in front of half the country by a spare worker! I’ve been wanting to get my hands on an unbinder and see what makes them tick for just //so// long. So: thank you for putting together this whole operation. I was worried they might not bother, but it seems Vanguard has rubbed off on them. They were just so filled with //humanitarian concern// that they brought one! So sweet. I should have the countermeasure up by next week. Why on Earth did you step up as bait?  Did you think they’d pull you out while you were still recognisable? Because I can promise you that even if they did cage me, you are not in a fixable state. Hm. I do not think the word for what you have done here is //bravery//, exactly; even we Levantine hunter-gatherers had words for “suicidal”. It should make your cerebrum an interesting reagent, if nothing else. Ah, and here they come. They’re just going through the chaff upstairs. I do wish you’d never invented gunpowder. Those things are just far too loud. Eve! Come on upstairs, dear. There are some very rude men upstairs. Yes, isn’t she just adorable? It took me a while to work out the telescoping ribcage. Put that away, darling, you’re getting lymph everywhere. And those fingernails! I’ll have you know they can hit a sparrow at half a kilometre. Just go on up, sweet. Dinner’s served. [[include :scp-wiki:component:wide-image-sizer]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:image-block name=http://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/local--files/girlraisingproject/light.jpg | caption=When I was a child, I dreamt of the paradise I was promised my spirit would one day rise to. There would be plentiful beasts, fruit on every tree, and night would never fall. Perhaps your cities do have some worth, after all. | align=center | width=100% ]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:license-box |author=Nice Try]] > **Filename:**goat.jpg > **Author:** SynthPanda_ > **License:** CC BY-SA 2.0 > **Source Link:** https://www.flickr.com/photos/195755885@N07/52425420391/ > **Filename:**woods.jpg > **Author:** SynthPanda_ > **License:** CC BY-SA 2.0 > **Source Link:** https://www.flickr.com/photos/195755885@N07/52614301372/ > **Filename:**ruins.jpg > **Author:** SynthPanda_ (edited by [[*user BAD_DATA]]) > **License:** CC-BY 2.0 > **Source Link:** https://www.flickr.com/photos/195755885@N07/54572111020/ > **Filename:**light.jpg > **Author:** SynthPanda_ > **License:** CC BY-SA 2.0 > **Source Link:** https://www.flickr.com/photos/195755885@N07/53096187810/ [[include :scp-wiki:component:license-box-end]]

i-didn-t-forget-pt-18-callum-michaels.raw_content:
While Jerry reunites with his comrades in containment, Evan finally drags the whole truth out of Callum, whose confession reveals that the world is in even more danger than the Foundation feared.

  • 

    close

    Info

    X

    CW: This tale includes depictions of captivity, manipulation and emotional abuse. It also contains mentions of solitary confinement and ritual human sacrifice as well as an allusion to sexual assault via mind control.

⚠️ content warning

Series Hub

◀◀ First Entry | ◀ Previous Entry | Next Entry ▶

More by this Author

Evan

Evan walks into the same interrogation chamber in which he last spoke to Callum. The former Fifthist looks up at him from across the table, smug as ever.

“Are we really doing this again so soon?” Callum asks.

“I think it’ll be different this time,” Evan says.

Callum sighs. “Fine. It’s not like I have anything better to do. I suppose you have more questions?”

“No. This time, I think I have answers.”

Jerry

The day after I made my arrangement with Dr. Light, I’m escorted to the medium security socialization area after a long day treating civilians with mental afflictions.

It’s a well-guarded room, totally enclosed and located deep within Site-17.

There are plenty of chairs and tables in the room, along with a handful of entertainment objects. There are some board games on shelves in the corner. There’s a foosball table near the center, and a television on the wall that is currently showing a music video.

However, each of these amenities is carefully controlled. All furniture is nailed to the floor or affixed firmly to the wall. There’s nothing in the room that can be thrown or used as a weapon, and nothing that could allow prisoners to communicate with the outside world.

Add to that the heavy metal door, the armed guards, and the fact that any escaping humanoid would have an entire facility to navigate before they got out, and this room is quite secure.

Still, for members of the Serpent’s Hand, to be allowed in here is an enormous privilege, one the Foundation is granting only on an extremely probative basis.

Light neglected to mention that part of the deal. The Foundation is allowing us in here in exchange for the information I gave, but if any of us piss off the Jailors, we’ll all be yanked back into solitary confinement.

That means I can’t fuck up. I can’t do anything that would prompt the Jailors to take this away from my comrades. Even though I know that’s exactly what the Jailors want me to think, I still can’t do it. It’s my fault Sean and the others got captured. I can’t do anything that would make their captivity worse.

There are around two dozen humanoids in medium security. Most of them are strangers, but my eyes snap right to the ones who are familiar.

There, sitting in a corner, already talking to each other, are Jack, Mike, and Sean. They turn to look at me as I enter the room.

I look back at them. They wear the same bluish uniforms all imprisoned anomalies wear, but I don’t see any wounds or scars. Their mood is somber, but they don’t seem broken.

Considering the magnitude of the clusterfuck I dragged them into, they’re doing a lot better than they could be.

That should make me feel better, but it doesn’t. If it weren’t for me, they’d still be free. They gave up their freedom for me, for my mission, a mission that was doomed from the start.

As soon as the guards undo my cuffs, I run up to them. I hug all three of them in turn, tears trickling to the floor beneath me. Words I’ve wanted to say for months come spilling out of me like water from a burst pipe. “I’m so sorry,” I say. “I’m so sorry I pulled you into all this.”

Sean shakes his head. “Don’t blame yourself,” he says.

“Don’t do that,” I say. “Don’t pretend it’s not my fault just to make me feel better. You got captured trying to rescue my brother. If I hadn’t made you guys help me, you’d still be free.”

“I inducted you into the Serpent’s Hand,” Sean says. “We knew the risks and chose to take them. Resistance is dangerous. It’s no one’s fault but the Jailors’.”

I shake my head. “No. You wouldn’t have come to this place if it weren’t for me, and it all turned out to be for nothing. Evan was…” I look up at him. I see no confusion, only concern. He knows. Of course he does. Jack and Mike saw Evan betray me. It was probably the first thing they told him.

“I’m sorry about your brother,” Sean says.

“I should’ve known,” I say. “He was wearing an MTF uniform. He was eating with them. I was so stupid to trust him.” An edge of anger creeps into my voice. Anger at Evan, for betraying me, and anger at myself, for falling for it.

“None of us knew it was a possibility,” Mike says.

“He was wearing a uniform!” I say.

“I know,” Sean says, “and I’m not saying you didn’t make a mistake, but a lot of people probably would have done the same thing. Besides, at least your brother hasn’t been suffering this whole time. He’s probably better off in that task force than in a cell.”

“What happened is worse,” I say. “He’s an enemy, now. He betrayed me.”

“I know,” Sean admits. He looks at me for a moment and seems to think better of continuing to speak, as if afraid his opinion on the issue would offend me.

I take a moment to contemplate what he’s suggesting, that Evan rotting miserable in a cell for six years would have been worse than what happened.

I spent six years having nightmares about my brother rotting alone in a cell. The entire time he was gone, I had no idea how he was being treated. I wasn’t even sure he was still alive.

Once I entered the Library and learned about the Foundation, the fearful unknown was replaced with a vivid image of Evan being treated the way Sean was treated as a teenager, the way most humanoid anomalies are treated by the Foundation. Do I really wish I’d found Evan like that?

I have to, don’t I? Not because I want him to suffer, but because, if he’d been a prisoner, he would have followed me to the Wanderer’s Library. I’d have brought him into the Hand, and my parents would’ve finally learned that their son was still alive.

A new image flashes in my head. Somewhere, right now, my mom is in tears, believing that she outlived both of her sons. The Jailors surely faked my death just as they did Evan’s, so now my parents think they’ve lost both their children.

Evan knew they’d do that when he helped the Jailors capture me. Whatever misery she’s suffering now, it’s his fault.

“Have you been okay since we last saw you?” Mike asks.

Of course not. No one in containment is okay.

“Don’t worry about me,” I say.

“We’re all going to worry about each other,” Sean says. “There’s no helping that.”

I close my eyes. I don’t want to tell them what I’ve been doing. I don’t want to tell them that I’ve also been helping the Jailors. Even though they trained me not to. Even though they spent months teaching me to shut down and give our enemies nothing.

“What’s wrong?” Mike asks.

I can’t lie to them, though. I can’t pretend I haven’t failed them. That would be yet another betrayal.

Tears trickle down my cheeks. “I’ve been helping them, too,” I say.

“What?” Sean asks. There it is. The anger I deserve. It’s almost comforting, knowing that, at least after this, I won’t be able to disappoint them any further.

“I’ve been letting them use my powers,” I say. “They’ve been putting people in front of me, civilians, victims of mind-control, and I’ve been curing them.”

“That’s all?” Sean asks.

“That, and the tidbit of information I used to get the four of us in here. It was about the Fifth Church. I don’t think they could use it against the Hand. Still… I failed you. You trained me to ignore them, to force my mind out of my body and give them nothing. Instead, I’ve been letting them manipulate and bargain with me.”

“What did they do?” Mike asks.

“They put a victim in front of me, someone who’d been cursed. I tried to do the fire thing. I tried to summon a vivid image to my mind and ignore them like you trained me to, but I only held out for a few minutes before I gave in and cured them of the spell that was torturing them.”

I expect anger. Judgement. Disappointment. Failing that, I expect some sugarcoating attempt to cheer me up. The last thing I expect is the genuine relief that passes across their faces.

“That was a horrible thing for them to do,” Sean says.

“I’m sorry for not holding out,” I say. “Now that they can use me to cure people, my brother is free to… well, I don’t know what he’s doing, but given that he’s a loyal Jailor, it’s probably bad.”

“It’s okay,” Sean says.

“No, it’s not!” I say.

“Listen,” Sean says, “I hate them too, but, if I had your powers, and if they locked me in a room with someone like that, I probably would’ve done the same thing. It might’ve even been the right thing to do.”

I look up at him. Is he serious? Could he really have just said that? “I… I’m helping them,” I say. “How could that be the right thing to do?”

“Are you doing anything that helps them hurt anyone?” Jack asks.

“Not directly,” I admit, after a moment, “but what I’m doing used to be my brother’s primary job. Now that I’m doing it, he’s free to go do Jailor things.”

“If you’d refused to treat those people,” Mike asks, “would the Jailors have used Evan to cure them, or would he be off doing whatever he’s doing, leaving them untreated?”

It takes me a moment to process the significance of this question. “The latter,” I admit. “At least, that’s what Evan said.”

“Then I think you made the right choice,” Sean says. “Those people don’t deserve to languish in a containment cell.”

“At least you got the Jailors to let someone go,” Jack adds.

I stare up at them.

The argument they just made, Evan also made it when he tried to recruit me to the Jailors right after he captured me.

“I decrease the number of people in Foundation custody. Before I came around, there were hundreds of mental anomalies whose victims had to be kept in containment for the rest of their lives. I’ve cured thousands of people like that, allowing them to be sent back to their families. I’ve freed more people from Foundation containment than the Serpent’s Hand ever will.”

Am I really hearing the same argument from Sean?

I try to keep my shock off my face, but, clearly, I’m failing.

“Look,” Jack says, “all we’re saying is, you’re being forced to make hard choices in here. Try to cut yourself some slack, okay? You’re doing the best you can.”

The best I can?

“You… actually think that?” I ask.

“I do,” Sean says. The others nod in agreement.

Could it be that they’re just saying this to cheer me up?

No. They wouldn’t lie to me like that. They wouldn’t treat me like a child. If they’re saying my decision is understandable, perhaps even defensible, that’s what they honestly believe.

I want to argue back, to explain why they should be disappointed in me, but I can’t find the words, and after I spend close to a minute trying and trying to think of something to say, I once again cave to temptation, and change the subject. “How have you guys been?” I ask.

They’ve been worse off than me.

Sean was moved to Site-17 almost immediately after his capture, and he’s been in high security containment ever since. All three of them have suffered the same mind-numbing isolation, only they haven’t had interactions with Evan, Dr. Light, my patients, or any other scrap of human contact. They’ve been completely alone for months.

“I’m so sorry,” I can’t help but say again. “You shouldn’t have had to suffer like that for my failure.”

“You got us out,” Jack says. “It’s thanks to you we’re in here. We can never thank you enough for that.”

“It was the least I could do, after getting you stuck here,” I say.

“Don’t think of it like that,” Sean says. “We embarked on this mission together. We got captured together. We got in here together.”

“You’d still be out if it weren’t for me,” I repeat.

“If we hadn’t been on your mission, we would’ve been on another,” Sean says. “It could have gone South, just like this one did. If that had happened, we probably never would have escaped solitary.”

My eyes are moist. I shake my head, but, once again, I’m not able to formulate an argument. I did get them out of high security containment, and taking Light’s deal was the only way I could’ve done that. In almost any other situation, that would’ve been impossible.

“We’re a team,” I say. “I had to help you.”

“Exactly,” Sean says. “We’re a team. We embarked on this mission together, we failed together, and we’re still together now.”

The others seem to agree with that, and I don’t have it in me to argue with them.

The heavy conversation dies down after that, and we set about just spending time together. We spend some time on the foosball table, and another chunk of time watching TV.

There’s another music video on, by the pop star Jimmy Pheonix. He’s a young singer, around Evan’s age. He exploded onto the scene about half a decade ago and has become one of the most popular musicians in the world.

His style could be best described as aggressively inoffensive, one of those pop stars cooked up in a corporate boardroom for maximumly broad appeal. I’m sure people who care deeply about music regard him as absolute trash. For example:

“Gods, do they have to play this?” Mike asks.

“Apparently,” Sean says.

“Eh, I think it’s fine,” Jack says.

The other two turn to look at him.

“What?” Jack asks.

“Nothing,” Mike says, looking away. “You can like whatever you want.”

“There’s probably an actual reason they’re playing this,” I say. “It’s not hard to imagine why they’d actively want to rot our brains with something mindless.”

“Just because it’s popular doesn’t mean it’s mindless,” Jack says.

“What’s that?” Mike asks. “I can’t hear you over the four chords.”

“None of his songs use the four chords,” Jack says. “Do you even know which chords the ‘four chords of pop music’ are?”

After half a minute of embarrassing silence, Mike admits he does not.

Socialization goes on for two hours. When it’s over, me and my comrades are allowed to exchange goodbyes, then we’re sent back to our cells.

We’re all still prisoners. They’re still suffering immensely for my failure, but at least I’m lightening their burden. At least they’re with friends, some of the time.

Maybe it’s pathetic that the bar has sunk so low, but this is the best day I’ve had in months. I can only hope it was for them, too. That’s the least I owe them.

Evan

Callum tilts his head. “Okay,” he admits, “you have me curious. What’s this epiphany you’ve had?”

“Do you know who Veronica Hall is?” Evan asks.

“The magician?”

“And Fifthist.”

“Is she? I hadn’t heard.”

That’s probably a lie, but it’s not an important one right now, so Evan doesn’t allow himself to get distracted by it.

“I talked to her yesterday,” Evan says. “She said some very interesting things. She knew about the Galaxy Plaza ritual, and she seemed to think of you as the one primarily responsible for its failure.”

Callum raises a brow. “Did she? I will admit that’s a bit interesting. I suppose it could be seen as my fault. The ritual might have worked if I hadn’t had it moved.”

Evan shakes his head. “It’s more than that,” he says. For a second, he has to fight down his nerves. He’s about to make a big claim. If he’s wrong, he’s going to make himself look really stupid, which could permanently damage his rapport with Callum.

He’s not wrong, though. His theory makes sense. It explains everything. It explains what all of this has to do with Cassidy Redwood. It explains why Callum chose to meddle with such an important ritual, when he could have easily taken revenge on Evan in another way. It explains how Callum could have been foolish enough to think that a ritual designed to require thousands of sacrifices would still work with only a few dozen.

Or, rather, it explains that he was never that foolish.

Evan looks Callum right in the eye. “I think you got the ritual moved to Galaxy Plaza knowing that would cause it to fail,” Evan says. “I think you wanted it to fail.”

For a moment, Callum is frozen. He’s clearly surprised. But is it the correctness of the claim that has him shocked, or its absurdity?

The smile that slowly creeps across Callum’s face does little to resolve this ambiguity. “Oh?” he asks. “What makes you think that?”

“Hall said something very interesting to me yesterday. ‘I told them that what didn’t work for Redwood wouldn’t work for us.’ She meant Cassidy Redwood, the Ortothan who tried and failed to resurrect her god with a blood sacrifice. Redwood left behind extensive notes detailing how she tried to reduce the number of sacrifices her ritual required.

“You’ve already admitted that you approached your father and asked him to move the ritual to Galaxy Plaza. I always took it for granted that you had enough pull with him to get him to say yes, but that doesn’t really make sense, does it? This ritual was the most important thing the church had ever attempted. There’s no way your father would allow its effectiveness to be jeopardized just so you could get revenge against me.”

“But it was moved,” Callum observes. “Clearly I did manage to convince the Church to move it.”

“And in order to do that, you had to pair your proposal with an argument that the ritual would still work. You had to provide some kind of explanation, grounded in thaumaturgic theory, for why such a tiny number of sacrifices would still be enough.”

“What about the giant machine Cassidy Redwood built? There was nothing like that at the Galaxy Plaza.”

“I’m sure you altered the details of the plan. You didn’t need to use every trick she did. You just borrowed enough ideas to create a somewhat convincing case that the ritual could be completed with fewer sacrifices. You didn’t even need to admit you got the idea from Redwood. Maybe Hall just made that connection later. Either way, you must have told them something.”

“And how do you know I was lying?” Callum asks. “Couldn’t I have honestly believed the ritual would work with fewer sacrifices?”

“No. You know magical theory too well.”

“I was a Fifthist. The same people who tried to take a bus to another solar system, remember?”

“But you’d been interacting with me for months. Fifthism’s grip on your mind had weakened.”

Evan takes one more second to push down his nerves. It’s time for the killing blow.

“In fact, I don’t think that weakened grip just made you too smart to think the ritual would still work. I think it made you want it to fail. I think, after months of being friends with me, my voice eroding the Starfish’s influence on you, a tiny bit of your conscience showed itself, just enough that you didn’t want to end the world.”

Callum stares up at Evan for several seconds. Slowly, as if out to milk the tension in the room for as long as he can, he closes his eyes and shakes his head. “Tsk, tsk, Evan. For a second, I really thought you had it all figured out, but then you had to start blabbering about my conscience.” He pauses for a moment, then looks Evan right in the eye. “My choice to sabotage the ritual had nothing to do with morality.”

“Then what did it have to do with?”

“I realized that I liked the world the way it was.”

“How’s that different?”

“Because it had less than nothing to do with other people’s wellbeing. Before you had me captured, I had money, power, and magic, and I was in a position to lord those things over the masses who lacked them. Most people didn’t even know magic existed. None of them had any way of protecting themselves against my spells. I could do whatever I wanted. I could make them do whatever I wanted.”

That makes Evan grimace. Jerry said something similar, a while back, that the Veil helps the world’s monsters by ensuring ordinary people don’t know how to defend themselves against them.

“I still don’t understand how you don’t see the appeal of it,” Callum continues. “In a clueless world, there was nothing stopping me from taking anything I wanted. I wanted a tome of arcane lore? I made someone sell it to me for a pittance. I wanted the hottest girl I knew to date me? She did. Everything I wanted, I got. I had power, and other people didn’t. Do you know enough about Fifthist doctrine to know what’s supposed to happen once the Fifth Church finally wins?”

“The world turns into a hellscape based on the Starfish’s warped imagination.”

“And with that newfound power, the Starfish destroys the barrier between desire and reality. All desires become real. All desires. Everyone would be able to bend reality to their whim, and if they decided they wanted to bend me, they’d be just as likely to succeed as they’d be to fail.”

Callum shakes his head.

“Why would I want that?” he asks. “Why would a wolf want the helpless sheep he fed on to become wolves as well? My family’s money wouldn’t matter. My magic wouldn’t be anything special. Everyone on earth would become my peer, and I don’t want peers. I want the kind of power that can only exist in an ordered world.”

Evan stares at Callum. Somehow, even though Evan’s initial guess was mostly right, Callum still managed to surprise and disappoint him.

Maybe Evan should have known better. He wants so badly to believe his high-school best friend is buried somewhere deep inside Callum, but maybe he isn’t. Maybe that person was only ever a mask, and the real Callum could only have sick, selfish reasons to do anything, even save the world.

“I was right about the rest of it, though?” Evan asks.

“Right enough that I’m impressed,” Callum admits. “I didn’t lie when I said I moved the ritual to Galaxy Plaza because I wanted revenge against you. I really did hate you for taking so much power away from me. At the same time, with the help of your magic voice, I’d come to recognize that the Church’s ultimate victory would, in its own way, do the same, so I hatched a plan to take care of both problems at once.

“I got my hands on Cassidy Redwood’s notes. I drafted a similar proposal for our ritual and presented it to my father. I argued that the smaller number of sacrifices would attract less attention. Bullshit, of course. I knew a few dozen sacrifices could never be enough. I knew that the only thing my new ritual would succeed at doing was luring you into danger. I told you something would happen, knowing you’d show up and try to save everyone. I thought you’d run in and get yourself killed, and once you did, everything would be back to the way it was before I met you, with me ruling as crown prince over a town of magicless simpletons.”

There it is, then. After six years, the full truth about the Galaxy Plaza disaster, with no loose ends or lingering questions.

As cathartic as it is to see it all laid out, Evan needs more than that to save the world again.

“If the Church were going to try the same ritual again,” Evan says, “what kind of venue would they need?”

“Please, don’t insult my intelligence by pretending you’re talking about a hypothetical. You’re here because something happened. Just come out and tell me.”

Evan sighs. On paper, he isn’t at liberty to disclose the situation to Callum. However, Callum’s talking right now because Evan earned a bit of his respect by figuring out what he did six years ago. For Callum to continue talking, Evan needs to keep that respect.

“Fine. I admit it. They’re trying again. What kind of venue do they need?”

Callum smiles. “That’s wonderful to hear. I hope they succeed. I certainly won’t be telling you anything that would help you stop them.”

“We just established that you don’t want the world to end.”

“I didn’t want it to end six years ago. My circumstances have changed since then. I no longer have money, power, or freedom. I’m not in a position to lord my magic over anyone. Compared to my life in here, maybe the Fifth Church’s new world would be an upgrade?”

“Their new world would be hell for anyone sane.”

“But that’s the beauty of it; there wouldn’t be anyone sane.”

Evan shakes his head. “I would still be sane, as would anyone I chose to interact with.”

“And you think I don’t want you to experience eternal torment?”

“Not if I can drag you down with me.”

That finally wipes the smile off Callum’s face.

“I promise you this,” Evan says, “if the Fifth Church does remake the world, and it’s because you didn’t tell me how to stop it, I will make sure you’re perfectly sane until the end of time. I will find you, and I will force you to endure every second of our new eternity just as agonizingly lucid as me.”

After a moment of trepidation, Callum shakes his head. “No, you won’t. You aren’t capable of that kind of vindictiveness. If the world is already beyond saving, you won’t torture me just out of spite.”

“In most situations, you’d be right,” Evan admits, “but you’re forgetting something. Jerry has my powers. He’d also be sane, trapped in an insane world of eternal torment.” Evan looks Callum in the eye. “I swear to you, if that happens to my little brother, and it’s your fault, I will happily dedicate the rest of my existence to punishing you.”

Callum meets his gaze for a moment. His smugness falters.

“Fine,” Callum says, through gritted teeth.

“How does the ritual work, and how would we stop it?”

“The Starlight Saga books have a memetic agent inside of them, similar to the one we put in Star Signals,” Callum says.

“That’s not true. We tested them.”

“You tested whether the books have any effect on your stupid D-Class. Your tests came back negative because the meme doesn’t do anything after it’s first implanted. It just lingers there, waiting to be activated.”

“Activated?”

“That’s what the ritual is for. It’s all part of a deal we made with an extra-universal entity. A tiny piece of that being’s essence is implanted in everyone who reads those books.”

Evan’s eyes widen. “Everyone?” Evan asks. “Everyone who’s read the Starlight Saga?”

With that, Callum’s smugness returns. “Every last one. As we speak, our trigger waits, latent, in tens of millions of readers all over the world.”

Evan takes a step backwards.”

“Once we give the entity the sacrifice we owe it,” Callum continues, “it’ll activate the trigger. All those minds will be ours, and they’ll start remaking the world.”

Tens of millions. Tens of millions of people. The implications are so heavy that it’s hard to stay standing. “Tens of millions would start to develop Ojai syndrome?”

“They wouldn’t ‘start to’ develop it. They’d become fully affected, instantly, just as if they’d read Star Signals cover to cover.”

“Instantly…” Evan doesn’t want to show Callum’s weakness, but he can’t keep the horror off his face. For that many people to fall fully under the control of the Fifth Church would be the greatest disaster in human history, anomalous or otherwise.

Callum’s delight is no less obvious than Evan’s fear. “The problem with Star Signals is that it was too slow. We’d barely started to spread the book when you identified it as a threat and started shutting us down, so the Church created a new memetic agent which would activate all at once, after it was already widespread. Once those millions of minds are under the Church’s control, they’ll begin the same ritual the Star Signals readers started, and, about two weeks later, the world will be remade.”

Evan takes a deep breath. Focus. He can’t let himself get overwhelmed. He needs to keep his head in the game. His job is to save the world. That’s all that matters.

“How can we figure out when and where the sacrifice will take place?” Evan asks.

“Before I interfered, the Church was going to do it at some massive nerd convention in California.”

“Why there?”

“The people we sacrifice have to be affected by the memetic agent. Part of the deal. Something about the entity getting to keep their souls. If the Church is planning to try again, they’ll pick somewhere where thousands of Starlight Saga readers have gathered.”

Back at the height of those books’ popularity, any large gathering of sci-fi fans would be full of people who’ve read them. Six years later… honestly, it wouldn’t be that different. There’d be thousands of events that could potentially qualify, and even if the Foundation identified and stopped one, all that would do is buy a bit of time. So long as that seed is prevalent, the Church can try again.

“Is there any way of purging that memetic seed from people?” Evan asks.

Callum shrugs. “You might be able to do it. You’re pretty good at cleaning magic gunk out of people’s brains. Still, given how many people there are to cure, and given that you have no way of identifying them, I don’t like your odds.”

Evan doesn’t like the Foundation’s odds, either.

The Foundation’s people need to have a very, very long talk about this information, and that talk needs to begin as soon as possible.

“I think that’s all my questions for now,” Evan says. “Thank you. What you just said might save the world.”

“What can I say? Threatening to torture someone for all eternity is a good way to get their secrets.”

“Still, you’ve done a good thing today. Maybe there’s—”

“Evan, it’s been five minutes since we went over this. You haven’t dug up some faint echo of my better nature. I don’t have a better nature. I said what I said because you threatened me. That’s all.”

“Fine,” Evan says. “Goodbye, then. Me or another Foundation agent may be back with more questions later. Be candid with them, or else.”

“Of course. Goodbye, and, from the bottom of my heart, I hope you fail.”

It’s almost enough to goad Evan into taking the last word, but that’d be as much of a victory for Callum as anything. Evan leaves.

Light is waiting outside. “Good work,” she says, though there isn’t any cheer in her voice.

“Thanks,” Evan says.

“I’m arranging an emergency meeting.”

“Of course.”

Light’s gaze lingers on him for a moment. He meets it. He does his best to force the worry off of his face.

She can probably still see it. After, he can tell she’s doing the same. The truth is, unless everything Callum just said is completely wrong, this is the gravest situation Evan has ever faced. Unless the Foundation does something very clever, very quickly, tens of millions of minds are going to be brought under the Fifth Church’s control.

Once that’s happened, it’s hard to imagine how even the Foundation could save the world.
